1 
1069  constexpr double kappa = 1e-6; /* m^2 / s */
1070  constexpr double reference_density = 3300; /* kg / m^3 */
1071  constexpr double reference_temperature = 293; /* K */
1072  constexpr double expansion_coefficient = 2e-5; /* 1/K */
1073  constexpr double specific_heat = 1250; /* J / K / kg */
1074  constexpr double radiogenic_heating = 7.4e-12; /* W / kg */
1075 *
1076 
1077  constexpr double R0 = 6371000.
1078 *
1079 - 2890000.; /* m */
1080  constexpr double R1 = 6371000.
1081 *
1082 - 35000.; /* m */
1083 *
1084  constexpr double T0 = 4000 + 273; /* K */
1085  constexpr double T1 = 700 + 273; /* K */
1086 *
1087 
1088  @endcode
1089 *
1090 * The next set of definitions are for functions that encode the density as a function of temperature, the gravity vector, and the initial values for the temperature. Again, all of these (along with the values they compute) are discussed in the introduction:
1091 *
1092 
1093 *
1094 * @code
1095  double density(const double temperature)
1096  {
1097  return (
1098  reference_density
1099  (1
1100 *
1101 - expansion_coefficient (temperature
1102 *
1103 - reference_temperature)));
1104  }
1105 *
1106 
1107  template <int dim>
1108  Tensor<1, dim> gravity_vector(const Point<dim> &p)
1109  {
1110  const double r = p.norm();
1111  return
1112 *
1113 -(1.245e-6 r + 7.714e13 / r / r) p / r;
1114  }
1115 *
1116 
1117 *
1118  template <int dim>
1119  class TemperatureInitialValues : public Function<dim>
1120  {
1121  public:
1122  TemperatureInitialValues()
1123  : Function<dim>(1)
1124  {}
1125 *
1126  virtual double value(const Point<dim> & p,
1127  const unsigned int component = 0) const override;
1128 *
1129  virtual void vector_value(const Point<dim> &p,
1130  Vector<double> & value) const override;
1131  };
1132 *
1133 
1134 *
1135  template <int dim>
1136  double TemperatureInitialValues<dim>::value(const Point<dim> &p,
1137  const unsigned int) const
1138  {
1139  const double r = p.norm();
1140  const double h = R1
1141 *
1142 - R0;
1143 *
1144  const double s = (r
1145 *
1146 - R0) / h;
1147  const double q =
1148  (dim == 3) ? std::max(0.0, cos(numbers::PI abs(p(2) / R1))) : 1.0;
1149  const double phi = std::atan2(p(0), p(1));
1150  const double tau = s + 0.2 s (1
1151 *
1152 - s) std::sin(6 phi) q;
1153 *
1154  return T0 (1.0
1155 *
1156 - tau) + T1 tau;
1157  }
1158 *
1159 
1160  template <int dim>
1161  void
1162  TemperatureInitialValues<dim>::vector_value(const Point<dim> &p,
1163  Vector<double> & values) const
1164  {
1165  for (unsigned int c = 0; c < this->n_components; ++c)
1166  values(c) = TemperatureInitialValues<dim>::value(p, c);
1167  }
1168 *
1169 
1170  @endcode
1171 *
1172 * As mentioned in the introduction we need to rescale the pressure to avoid the relative ill-conditioning of the momentum and mass conservation equations. The scaling factor is @f$\frac{\eta}{L}@f$ where @f$L@f$ was a typical length scale. By experimenting it turns out that a good length scale is the diameter of plumes, which is around 10 km:
1173 *
1174 
1175 *
1176 * @code
1177  constexpr double pressure_scaling = eta / 10000;
1178 *
1179  @endcode
1180 *
1181 * The final number in this namespace is a constant that denotes the number of seconds per (average, tropical) year. We use this only when generating screen output: internally, all computations of this program happen in SI units (kilogram, meter, seconds) but writing geological times in seconds yields numbers that one can't relate to reality, and so we convert to years using the factor defined here:
1182 *
1183 
1184 *
1185 * @code
1186  const double year_in_seconds = 60 60 24 365.2425;
1187 *
1188  } // namespace EquationData
1189 *
1190 
1191 *
1192  @endcode
1193 *
1194 * <a name="PreconditioningtheStokessystem"></a> <h3>Preconditioning the Stokes system</h3>
1195 *
1196 
1197 *
1198 * This namespace implements the preconditioner. As discussed in the introduction, this preconditioner differs in a number of key portions from the one used in @ref step_31 "step-31" . Specifically, it is a right preconditioner, implementing the matrix
1199 
1200 *
1201 * @f{align*}
1202  \left(\begin{array}{cc}A^{-1} & B^T
1203  \\0 & S^{-1}
1204  \end{array}\right)
1205  @f}
1206 * where the two inverse matrix operations are approximated by linear solvers or, if the right flag is given to the constructor of this class, by a single AMG V-cycle for the velocity block. The three code blocks of the <code>vmult</code> function implement the multiplications with the three blocks of this preconditioner matrix and should be self explanatory if you have read through @ref step_31 "step-31" or the discussion of composing solvers in @ref step_20 "step-20" .
1207 *
1208 
1209 *
1210 * @code
1211  namespace LinearSolvers
1212  {
1213  template <class PreconditionerTypeA, class PreconditionerTypeMp>
1214  class BlockSchurPreconditioner : public Subscriptor
1215  {
1216  public:
1217  BlockSchurPreconditioner(const TrilinosWrappers::BlockSparseMatrix &S,
1218  const TrilinosWrappers::BlockSparseMatrix &Spre,
1219  const PreconditionerTypeMp &Mppreconditioner,
1220  const PreconditionerTypeA & Apreconditioner,
1221  const bool do_solve_A)
1222  : stokes_matrix(&S)
1223  , stokes_preconditioner_matrix(&Spre)
1224  , mp_preconditioner(Mppreconditioner)
1225  , a_preconditioner(Apreconditioner)
1226  , do_solve_A(do_solve_A)
1227  {}
1228 *
1229  void vmult(TrilinosWrappers::MPI::BlockVector & dst,
1230  const TrilinosWrappers::MPI::BlockVector &src) const
1231  {
1232  TrilinosWrappers::MPI::Vector utmp(src.block(0));
1233 *
1234  {
1235  SolverControl solver_control(5000, 1e-6 src.block(1).l2_norm());
1236 *
1237  SolverCG<TrilinosWrappers::MPI::Vector> solver(solver_control);
1238 *
1239  solver.solve(stokes_preconditioner_matrix->block(1, 1),
1240  dst.block(1),
1241  src.block(1),
1242  mp_preconditioner);
1243 *
1244  dst.block(1)=
1245 *
1246 -1.0;
1247  }
1248 *
1249  {
1250  stokes_matrix->block(0, 1).vmult(utmp, dst.block(1));
1251  utmp=
1252 *
1253 -1.0;
1254  utmp.add(src.block(0));
1255  }
1256 *
1257  if (do_solve_A == true)
1258  {
1259  SolverControl solver_control(5000, utmp.l2_norm() 1e-2);
1260  TrilinosWrappers::SolverCG solver(solver_control);
1261  solver.solve(stokes_matrix->block(0, 0),
1262  dst.block(0),
1263  utmp,
1264  a_preconditioner);
1265  }
1266  else
1267  a_preconditioner.vmult(dst.block(0), utmp);
1268  }
1269 *
1270  private:
1271  const SmartPointer<const TrilinosWrappers::BlockSparseMatrix>
1272  stokes_matrix;
1273  const SmartPointer<const TrilinosWrappers::BlockSparseMatrix>
1274  stokes_preconditioner_matrix;
1275  const PreconditionerTypeMp &mp_preconditioner;
1276  const PreconditionerTypeA & a_preconditioner;
1277  const bool do_solve_A;
1278  };
1279  } // namespace LinearSolvers
1280 *
1281 
1282 *
1283  @endcode
1284 *
1285 * <a name="Definitionofassemblydatastructures"></a> <h3>Definition of assembly data structures</h3>
1286 * As described in the introduction, we will use the WorkStream mechanism discussed in the @ref threads module to parallelize operations among the processors of a single machine. The WorkStream class requires that data is passed around in two kinds of data structures, one for scratch data and one to pass data from the assembly function to the function that copies local contributions into global objects.
1287 * The following namespace (and the two sub-namespaces) contains a collection of data structures that serve this purpose, one pair for each of the four operations discussed in the introduction that we will want to parallelize. Each assembly routine gets two sets of data: a Scratch array that collects all the classes and arrays that are used for the calculation of the cell contribution, and a CopyData array that keeps local matrices and vectors which will be written into the global matrix. Whereas CopyData is a container for the final data that is written into the global matrices and vector (and, thus, absolutely necessary), the Scratch arrays are merely there for performance reasons &mdash; it would be much more expensive to set up a FEValues object on each cell, than creating it only once and updating some derivative data.
1288 * @ref step_31 "step-31" had four assembly routines: One for the preconditioner matrix of the Stokes system, one for the Stokes matrix and right hand side, one for the temperature matrices and one for the right hand side of the temperature equation. We here organize the scratch arrays and CopyData objects for each of those four assembly components using a <code>struct</code> environment (since we consider these as temporary objects we pass around, rather than classes that implement functionality of their own, though this is a more subjective point of view to distinguish between <code>struct</code>s and <code>class</code> es).
1289 * Regarding the Scratch objects, each struct is equipped with a constructor that creates an @ref FEValues object using the @ref FiniteElement , Quadrature, @ref Mapping (which describes the interpolation of curved boundaries), and @ref UpdateFlags instances. Moreover, we manually implement a copy constructor (since the FEValues class is not copyable by itself), and provide some additional vector fields that are used to hold intermediate data during the computation of local contributions.
1290 * Let us start with the scratch arrays and, specifically, the one used for assembly of the Stokes preconditioner:
1291 *
1292 
1293 *
1294 * @code
1295  namespace Assembly
1296  {
1297  namespace Scratch
1298  {
1299  template <int dim>
1300  struct StokesPreconditioner
1301  {
1302  StokesPreconditioner(const FiniteElement<dim> &stokes_fe,
1303  const Quadrature<dim> & stokes_quadrature,
1304  const Mapping<dim> & mapping,
1305  const UpdateFlags update_flags);
1306 *
1307  StokesPreconditioner(const StokesPreconditioner &data);
1308 *
1309 
1310  FEValues<dim> stokes_fe_values;
1311 *
1312  std::vector<Tensor<2, dim>> grad_phi_u;
1313  std::vector<double> phi_p;
1314  };
1315 *
1316  template <int dim>
1317  StokesPreconditioner<dim>::StokesPreconditioner(
1318  const FiniteElement<dim> &stokes_fe,
1319  const Quadrature<dim> & stokes_quadrature,
1320  const Mapping<dim> & mapping,
1321  const UpdateFlags update_flags)
1322  : stokes_fe_values(mapping, stokes_fe, stokes_quadrature, update_flags)
1323  , grad_phi_u(stokes_fe.n_dofs_per_cell())
1324  , phi_p(stokes_fe.n_dofs_per_cell())
1325  {}
1326 *
1327 
1328 *
1329  template <int dim>
1330  StokesPreconditioner<dim>::StokesPreconditioner(
1331  const StokesPreconditioner &scratch)
1332  : stokes_fe_values(scratch.stokes_fe_values.get_mapping(),
1333  scratch.stokes_fe_values.get_fe(),
1334  scratch.stokes_fe_values.get_quadrature(),
1335  scratch.stokes_fe_values.get_update_flags())
1336  , grad_phi_u(scratch.grad_phi_u)
1337  , phi_p(scratch.phi_p)
1338  {}
1339 *
1340 
1341 *
1342  @endcode
1343 *
1344 * The next one is the scratch object used for the assembly of the full Stokes system. Observe that we derive the StokesSystem scratch class from the StokesPreconditioner class above. We do this because all the objects that are necessary for the assembly of the preconditioner are also needed for the actual matrix system and right hand side, plus some extra data. This makes the program more compact. Note also that the assembly of the Stokes system and the temperature right hand side further down requires data from temperature and velocity, respectively, so we actually need two FEValues objects for those two cases.
1345 *
1346 
1347 *
1348 * @code
1349  template <int dim>
1350  struct StokesSystem : public StokesPreconditioner<dim>
1351  {
1352  StokesSystem(const FiniteElement<dim> &stokes_fe,
1353  const Mapping<dim> & mapping,
1354  const Quadrature<dim> & stokes_quadrature,
1355  const UpdateFlags stokes_update_flags,
1356  const FiniteElement<dim> &temperature_fe,
1357  const UpdateFlags temperature_update_flags);
1358 *
1359  StokesSystem(const StokesSystem<dim> &data);
1360 *
1361 
1362  FEValues<dim> temperature_fe_values;
1363 *
1364  std::vector<Tensor<1, dim>> phi_u;
1365  std::vector<SymmetricTensor<2, dim>> grads_phi_u;
1366  std::vector<double> div_phi_u;
1367 *
1368  std::vector<double> old_temperature_values;
1369  };
1370 *
1371 
1372  template <int dim>
1373  StokesSystem<dim>::StokesSystem(
1374  const FiniteElement<dim> &stokes_fe,
1375  const Mapping<dim> & mapping,
1376  const Quadrature<dim> & stokes_quadrature,
1377  const UpdateFlags stokes_update_flags,
1378  const FiniteElement<dim> &temperature_fe,
1379  const UpdateFlags temperature_update_flags)
1380  : StokesPreconditioner<dim>(stokes_fe,
1381  stokes_quadrature,
1382  mapping,
1383  stokes_update_flags)
1384  , temperature_fe_values(mapping,
1385  temperature_fe,
1386  stokes_quadrature,
1387  temperature_update_flags)
1388  , phi_u(stokes_fe.n_dofs_per_cell())
1389  , grads_phi_u(stokes_fe.n_dofs_per_cell())
1390  , div_phi_u(stokes_fe.n_dofs_per_cell())
1391  , old_temperature_values(stokes_quadrature.size())
1392  {}
1393 *
1394 
1395  template <int dim>
1396  StokesSystem<dim>::StokesSystem(const StokesSystem<dim> &scratch)
1397  : StokesPreconditioner<dim>(scratch)
1398  , temperature_fe_values(
1399  scratch.temperature_fe_values.get_mapping(),
1400  scratch.temperature_fe_values.get_fe(),
1401  scratch.temperature_fe_values.get_quadrature(),
1402  scratch.temperature_fe_values.get_update_flags())
1403  , phi_u(scratch.phi_u)
1404  , grads_phi_u(scratch.grads_phi_u)
1405  , div_phi_u(scratch.div_phi_u)
1406  , old_temperature_values(scratch.old_temperature_values)
1407  {}
1408 *
1409 
1410  @endcode
1411 *
1412 * After defining the objects used in the assembly of the Stokes system, we do the same for the assembly of the matrices necessary for the temperature system. The general structure is very similar:
1413 *
1414 
1415 *
1416 * @code
1417  template <int dim>
1418  struct TemperatureMatrix
1419  {
1420  TemperatureMatrix(const FiniteElement<dim> &temperature_fe,
1421  const Mapping<dim> & mapping,
1422  const Quadrature<dim> & temperature_quadrature);
1423 *
1424  TemperatureMatrix(const TemperatureMatrix &data);
1425 *
1426 
1427  FEValues<dim> temperature_fe_values;
1428 *
1429  std::vector<double> phi_T;
1430  std::vector<Tensor<1, dim>> grad_phi_T;
1431  };
1432 *
1433 
1434  template <int dim>
1435  TemperatureMatrix<dim>::TemperatureMatrix(
1436  const FiniteElement<dim> &temperature_fe,
1437  const Mapping<dim> & mapping,
1438  const Quadrature<dim> & temperature_quadrature)
1439  : temperature_fe_values(mapping,
1440  temperature_fe,
1441  temperature_quadrature,
1442  update_values | update_gradients |
1443  update_JxW_values)
1444  , phi_T(temperature_fe.n_dofs_per_cell())
1445  , grad_phi_T(temperature_fe.n_dofs_per_cell())
1446  {}
1447 *
1448 
1449  template <int dim>
1450  TemperatureMatrix<dim>::TemperatureMatrix(
1451  const TemperatureMatrix &scratch)
1452  : temperature_fe_values(
1453  scratch.temperature_fe_values.get_mapping(),
1454  scratch.temperature_fe_values.get_fe(),
1455  scratch.temperature_fe_values.get_quadrature(),
1456  scratch.temperature_fe_values.get_update_flags())
1457  , phi_T(scratch.phi_T)
1458  , grad_phi_T(scratch.grad_phi_T)
1459  {}
1460 *
1461 
1462  @endcode
1463 *
1464 * The final scratch object is used in the assembly of the right hand side of the temperature system. This object is significantly larger than the ones above because a lot more quantities enter the computation of the right hand side of the temperature equation. In particular, the temperature values and gradients of the previous two time steps need to be evaluated at the quadrature points, as well as the velocities and the strain rates (i.e. the symmetric gradients of the velocity) that enter the right hand side as friction heating terms. Despite the number of terms, the following should be rather self explanatory:
1465 *
1466 
1467 *
1468 * @code
1469  template <int dim>
1470  struct TemperatureRHS
1471  {
1472  TemperatureRHS(const FiniteElement<dim> &temperature_fe,
1473  const FiniteElement<dim> &stokes_fe,
1474  const Mapping<dim> & mapping,
1475  const Quadrature<dim> & quadrature);
1476 *
1477  TemperatureRHS(const TemperatureRHS &data);
1478 *
1479 
1480  FEValues<dim> temperature_fe_values;
1481  FEValues<dim> stokes_fe_values;
1482 *
1483  std::vector<double> phi_T;
1484  std::vector<Tensor<1, dim>> grad_phi_T;
1485 *
1486  std::vector<Tensor<1, dim>> old_velocity_values;
1487  std::vector<Tensor<1, dim>> old_old_velocity_values;
1488 *
1489  std::vector<SymmetricTensor<2, dim>> old_strain_rates;
1490  std::vector<SymmetricTensor<2, dim>> old_old_strain_rates;
1491 *
1492  std::vector<double> old_temperature_values;
1493  std::vector<double> old_old_temperature_values;
1494  std::vector<Tensor<1, dim>> old_temperature_grads;
1495  std::vector<Tensor<1, dim>> old_old_temperature_grads;
1496  std::vector<double> old_temperature_laplacians;
1497  std::vector<double> old_old_temperature_laplacians;
1498  };
1499 *
1500 
1501  template <int dim>
1502  TemperatureRHS<dim>::TemperatureRHS(
1503  const FiniteElement<dim> &temperature_fe,
1504  const FiniteElement<dim> &stokes_fe,
1505  const Mapping<dim> & mapping,
1506  const Quadrature<dim> & quadrature)
1507  : temperature_fe_values(mapping,
1508  temperature_fe,
1509  quadrature,
1510  update_values | update_gradients |
1511  update_hessians | update_quadrature_points |
1512  update_JxW_values)
1513  , stokes_fe_values(mapping,
1514  stokes_fe,
1515  quadrature,
1516  update_values | update_gradients)
1517  , phi_T(temperature_fe.n_dofs_per_cell())
1518  , grad_phi_T(temperature_fe.n_dofs_per_cell())
1519  ,
1520 *
1521  old_velocity_values(quadrature.size())
1522  , old_old_velocity_values(quadrature.size())
1523  , old_strain_rates(quadrature.size())
1524  , old_old_strain_rates(quadrature.size())
1525  ,
1526 *
1527  old_temperature_values(quadrature.size())
1528  , old_old_temperature_values(quadrature.size())
1529  , old_temperature_grads(quadrature.size())
1530  , old_old_temperature_grads(quadrature.size())
1531  , old_temperature_laplacians(quadrature.size())
1532  , old_old_temperature_laplacians(quadrature.size())
1533  {}
1534 *
1535 
1536  template <int dim>
1537  TemperatureRHS<dim>::TemperatureRHS(const TemperatureRHS &scratch)
1538  : temperature_fe_values(
1539  scratch.temperature_fe_values.get_mapping(),
1540  scratch.temperature_fe_values.get_fe(),
1541  scratch.temperature_fe_values.get_quadrature(),
1542  scratch.temperature_fe_values.get_update_flags())
1543  , stokes_fe_values(scratch.stokes_fe_values.get_mapping(),
1544  scratch.stokes_fe_values.get_fe(),
1545  scratch.stokes_fe_values.get_quadrature(),
1546  scratch.stokes_fe_values.get_update_flags())
1547  , phi_T(scratch.phi_T)
1548  , grad_phi_T(scratch.grad_phi_T)
1549  ,
1550 *
1551  old_velocity_values(scratch.old_velocity_values)
1552  , old_old_velocity_values(scratch.old_old_velocity_values)
1553  , old_strain_rates(scratch.old_strain_rates)
1554  , old_old_strain_rates(scratch.old_old_strain_rates)
1555  ,
1556 *
1557  old_temperature_values(scratch.old_temperature_values)
1558  , old_old_temperature_values(scratch.old_old_temperature_values)
1559  , old_temperature_grads(scratch.old_temperature_grads)
1560  , old_old_temperature_grads(scratch.old_old_temperature_grads)
1561  , old_temperature_laplacians(scratch.old_temperature_laplacians)
1562  , old_old_temperature_laplacians(scratch.old_old_temperature_laplacians)
1563  {}
1564  } // namespace Scratch
1565 *
1566 
1567  @endcode
1568 *
1569 * The CopyData objects are even simpler than the Scratch objects as all they have to do is to store the results of local computations until they can be copied into the global matrix or vector objects. These structures therefore only need to provide a constructor, a copy operation, and some arrays for local matrix, local vectors and the relation between local and global degrees of freedom (a.k.a. <code>local_dof_indices</code> ). Again, we have one such structure for each of the four operations we will parallelize using the WorkStream class:
1570 *
1571 
1572 *
1573 * @code
1574  namespace CopyData
1575  {
1576  template <int dim>
1577  struct StokesPreconditioner
1578  {
1579  StokesPreconditioner(const FiniteElement<dim> &stokes_fe);
1580  StokesPreconditioner(const StokesPreconditioner &data);
1581  StokesPreconditioner &operator=(const StokesPreconditioner &) = default;
1582 *
1583  FullMatrix<double> local_matrix;
1584  std::vector<types::global_dof_index> local_dof_indices;
1585  };
1586 *
1587  template <int dim>
1588  StokesPreconditioner<dim>::StokesPreconditioner(
1589  const FiniteElement<dim> &stokes_fe)
1590  : local_matrix(stokes_fe.n_dofs_per_cell(), stokes_fe.n_dofs_per_cell())
1591  , local_dof_indices(stokes_fe.n_dofs_per_cell())
1592  {}
1593 *
1594  template <int dim>
1595  StokesPreconditioner<dim>::StokesPreconditioner(
1596  const StokesPreconditioner &data)
1597  : local_matrix(data.local_matrix)
1598  , local_dof_indices(data.local_dof_indices)
1599  {}
1600 *
1601 
1602 *
1603  template <int dim>
1604  struct StokesSystem : public StokesPreconditioner<dim>
1605  {
1606  StokesSystem(const FiniteElement<dim> &stokes_fe);
1607 *
1608  Vector<double> local_rhs;
1609  };
1610 *
1611  template <int dim>
1612  StokesSystem<dim>::StokesSystem(const FiniteElement<dim> &stokes_fe)
1613  : StokesPreconditioner<dim>(stokes_fe)
1614  , local_rhs(stokes_fe.n_dofs_per_cell())
1615  {}
1616 *
1617 
1618 *
1619  template <int dim>
1620  struct TemperatureMatrix
1621  {
1622  TemperatureMatrix(const FiniteElement<dim> &temperature_fe);
1623 *
1624  FullMatrix<double> local_mass_matrix;
1625  FullMatrix<double> local_stiffness_matrix;
1626  std::vector<types::global_dof_index> local_dof_indices;
1627  };
1628 *
1629  template <int dim>
1630  TemperatureMatrix<dim>::TemperatureMatrix(
1631  const FiniteElement<dim> &temperature_fe)
1632  : local_mass_matrix(temperature_fe.n_dofs_per_cell(),
1633  temperature_fe.n_dofs_per_cell())
1634  , local_stiffness_matrix(temperature_fe.n_dofs_per_cell(),
1635  temperature_fe.n_dofs_per_cell())
1636  , local_dof_indices(temperature_fe.n_dofs_per_cell())
1637  {}
1638 *
1639 
1640 *
1641  template <int dim>
1642  struct TemperatureRHS
1643  {
1644  TemperatureRHS(const FiniteElement<dim> &temperature_fe);
1645 *
1646  Vector<double> local_rhs;
1647  std::vector<types::global_dof_index> local_dof_indices;
1648  FullMatrix<double> matrix_for_bc;
1649  };
1650 *
1651  template <int dim>
1652  TemperatureRHS<dim>::TemperatureRHS(
1653  const FiniteElement<dim> &temperature_fe)
1654  : local_rhs(temperature_fe.n_dofs_per_cell())
1655  , local_dof_indices(temperature_fe.n_dofs_per_cell())
1656  , matrix_for_bc(temperature_fe.n_dofs_per_cell(),
1657  temperature_fe.n_dofs_per_cell())
1658  {}
1659  } // namespace CopyData
1660  } // namespace Assembly
1661 *
1662 
1663 *
1664  @endcode
1665 *
1666 * <a name="ThecodeBoussinesqFlowProblemcodeclasstemplate"></a> <h3>The <code>BoussinesqFlowProblem</code> class template</h3>
1667 * This is the declaration of the main class. It is very similar to @ref step_31 "step-31" but there are a number differences we will comment on below.
1668 * The top of the class is essentially the same as in @ref step_31 "step-31" , listing the public methods and a set of private functions that do the heavy lifting. Compared to @ref step_31 "step-31" there are only two additions to this section: the function <code>get_cfl_number()</code> that computes the maximum CFL number over all cells which we then compute the global time step from, and the function <code>get_entropy_variation()</code> that is used in the computation of the entropy stabilization. It is akin to the <code>get_extrapolated_temperature_range()</code> we have used in @ref step_31 "step-31" for this purpose, but works on the entropy instead of the temperature instead.
1669 *
1670 
1671 *
1672 * @code
1673  template <int dim>
1674  class BoussinesqFlowProblem
1675  {
1676  public:
1677  struct Parameters;
1678  BoussinesqFlowProblem(Parameters &parameters);
1679  void run();
1680 *
1681  private:
1682  void setup_dofs();
1683  void assemble_stokes_preconditioner();
1684  void build_stokes_preconditioner();
1685  void assemble_stokes_system();
1686  void assemble_temperature_matrix();
1687  void assemble_temperature_system(const double maximal_velocity);
1688  double get_maximal_velocity() const;
1689  double get_cfl_number() const;
1690  double get_entropy_variation(const double average_temperature) const;
1691  std::pair<double, double> get_extrapolated_temperature_range() const;
1692  void solve();
1693  void output_results();
1694  void refine_mesh(const unsigned int max_grid_level);
1695 *
1696  double compute_viscosity(
1697  const std::vector<double> & old_temperature,
1698  const std::vector<double> & old_old_temperature,
1699  const std::vector<Tensor<1, dim>> &old_temperature_grads,
1700  const std::vector<Tensor<1, dim>> &old_old_temperature_grads,
1701  const std::vector<double> & old_temperature_laplacians,
1702  const std::vector<double> & old_old_temperature_laplacians,
1703  const std::vector<Tensor<1, dim>> &old_velocity_values,
1704  const std::vector<Tensor<1, dim>> &old_old_velocity_values,
1705  const std::vector<SymmetricTensor<2, dim>> &old_strain_rates,
1706  const std::vector<SymmetricTensor<2, dim>> &old_old_strain_rates,
1707  const double global_u_infty,
1708  const double global_T_variation,
1709  const double average_temperature,
1710  const double global_entropy_variation,
1711  const double cell_diameter) const;
1712 *
1713  public:
1714  @endcode
1715 *
1716 * The first significant new component is the definition of a struct for the parameters according to the discussion in the introduction. This structure is initialized by reading from a parameter file during construction of this object.
1717 *
1718 
1719 *
1720 * @code
1721  struct Parameters
1722  {
1723  Parameters(const std::string &parameter_filename);
1724 *
1725  static void declare_parameters(ParameterHandler &prm);
1726  void parse_parameters(ParameterHandler &prm);
1727 *
1728  double end_time;
1729 *
1730  unsigned int initial_global_refinement;
1731  unsigned int initial_adaptive_refinement;
1732 *
1733  bool generate_graphical_output;
1734  unsigned int graphical_output_interval;
1735 *
1736  unsigned int adaptive_refinement_interval;
1737 *
1738  double stabilization_alpha;
1739  double stabilization_c_R;
1740  double stabilization_beta;
1741 *
1742  unsigned int stokes_velocity_degree;
1743  bool use_locally_conservative_discretization;
1744 *
1745  unsigned int temperature_degree;
1746  };
1747 *
1748  private:
1749  Parameters &parameters;
1750 *
1751  @endcode
1752 *
1753 * The <code>pcout</code> (for <i>%parallel <code>std::cout</code></i>) object is used to simplify writing output: each MPI process can use this to generate output as usual, but since each of these processes will (hopefully) produce the same output it will just be replicated many times over; with the ConditionalOStream class, only the output generated by one MPI process will actually be printed to screen, whereas the output by all the other threads will simply be forgotten.
1754 *
1755 
1756 *
1757 * @code
1758  ConditionalOStream pcout;
1759 *
1760  @endcode
1761 *
1762 * The following member variables will then again be similar to those in @ref step_31 "step-31" (and to other tutorial programs). As mentioned in the introduction, we fully distribute computations, so we will have to use the parallel::distributed::Triangulation class (see @ref step_40 "step-40" ) but the remainder of these variables is rather standard with two exceptions:
1763 *
1764 
1765 *
1766 *
1767 
1768 *
1769 *
1770 
1771 *
1772 *
1773 
1774 *
1775 *
1776 
1777 *
1778 *
1779 
1780 *
1781 *
1782 
1783 *
1784 *
1785 
1786 *
1787 *
1788 
1789 *
1790 *
1791 * - The <code>mapping</code> variable is used to denote a higher-order polynomial mapping. As mentioned in the introduction, we use this mapping when forming integrals through quadrature for all cells that are adjacent to either the inner or outer boundaries of our domain where the boundary is curved.
1792 *
1793 
1794 *
1795 *
1796 
1797 *
1798 *
1799 
1800 *
1801 *
1802 
1803 *
1804 *
1805 
1806 *
1807 *
1808 
1809 *
1810 *
1811 
1812 *
1813 *
1814 
1815 *
1816 *
1817 
1818 *
1819 *
1820 * - In a bit of naming confusion, you will notice below that some of the variables from namespace TrilinosWrappers are taken from namespace TrilinosWrappers::MPI (such as the right hand side vectors) whereas others are not (such as the various matrices). This is due to legacy reasons. We will frequently have to query velocities and temperatures at arbitrary quadrature points; consequently, rather than importing ghost information of a vector whenever we need access to degrees of freedom that are relevant locally but owned by another processor, we solve linear systems in %parallel but then immediately initialize a vector including ghost entries of the solution for further processing. The various <code>*_solution</code> vectors are therefore filled immediately after solving their respective linear system in %parallel and will always contain values for all @ref GlossLocallyRelevantDof "locally relevant degrees of freedom"; the fully distributed vectors that we obtain from the solution process and that only ever contain the @ref GlossLocallyOwnedDof "locally owned degrees of freedom" are destroyed immediately after the solution process and after we have copied the relevant values into the member variable vectors.
1821 *
1822 
1823 *
1824 * @code
1825  parallel::distributed::Triangulation<dim> triangulation;
1826  double global_Omega_diameter;
1827 *
1828  const MappingQ<dim> mapping;
1829 *
1830  const FESystem<dim> stokes_fe;
1831  DoFHandler<dim> stokes_dof_handler;
1832  AffineConstraints<double> stokes_constraints;
1833 *
1834  TrilinosWrappers::BlockSparseMatrix stokes_matrix;
1835  TrilinosWrappers::BlockSparseMatrix stokes_preconditioner_matrix;
1836 *
1837  TrilinosWrappers::MPI::BlockVector stokes_solution;
1838  TrilinosWrappers::MPI::BlockVector old_stokes_solution;
1839  TrilinosWrappers::MPI::BlockVector stokes_rhs;
1840 *
1841 
1842  FE_Q<dim> temperature_fe;
1843  DoFHandler<dim> temperature_dof_handler;
1844  AffineConstraints<double> temperature_constraints;
1845 *
1846  TrilinosWrappers::SparseMatrix temperature_mass_matrix;
1847  TrilinosWrappers::SparseMatrix temperature_stiffness_matrix;
1848  TrilinosWrappers::SparseMatrix temperature_matrix;
1849 *
1850  TrilinosWrappers::MPI::Vector temperature_solution;
1851  TrilinosWrappers::MPI::Vector old_temperature_solution;
1852  TrilinosWrappers::MPI::Vector old_old_temperature_solution;
1853  TrilinosWrappers::MPI::Vector temperature_rhs;
1854 *
1855 
1856  double time_step;
1857  double old_time_step;
1858  unsigned int timestep_number;
1859 *
1860  std::shared_ptr<TrilinosWrappers::PreconditionAMG> Amg_preconditioner;
1861  std::shared_ptr<TrilinosWrappers::PreconditionJacobi> Mp_preconditioner;
1862  std::shared_ptr<TrilinosWrappers::PreconditionJacobi> T_preconditioner;
1863 *
1864  bool rebuild_stokes_matrix;
1865  bool rebuild_stokes_preconditioner;
1866  bool rebuild_temperature_matrices;
1867  bool rebuild_temperature_preconditioner;
1868 *
1869  @endcode
1870 *
1871 * The next member variable, <code>computing_timer</code> is used to conveniently account for compute time spent in certain "sections" of the code that are repeatedly entered. For example, we will enter (and leave) sections for Stokes matrix assembly and would like to accumulate the run time spent in this section over all time steps. Every so many time steps as well as at the end of the program (through the destructor of the TimerOutput class) we will then produce a nice summary of the times spent in the different sections into which we categorize the run-time of this program.
1872 *
1873 
1874 *
1875 * @code
1876  TimerOutput computing_timer;
1877 *
1878  @endcode
1879 *
1880 * After these member variables we have a number of auxiliary functions that have been broken out of the ones listed above. Specifically, there are first three functions that we call from <code>setup_dofs</code> and then the ones that do the assembling of linear systems:
1881 *
1882 
1883 *
1884 * @code
1885  void setup_stokes_matrix(
1886  const std::vector<IndexSet> &stokes_partitioning,
1887  const std::vector<IndexSet> &stokes_relevant_partitioning);
1888  void setup_stokes_preconditioner(
1889  const std::vector<IndexSet> &stokes_partitioning,
1890  const std::vector<IndexSet> &stokes_relevant_partitioning);
1891  void setup_temperature_matrices(
1892  const IndexSet &temperature_partitioning,
1893  const IndexSet &temperature_relevant_partitioning);
1894 *
1895 
1896  @endcode
1897 *
1898 * Following the @ref MTWorkStream "task-based parallelization" paradigm, we split all the assembly routines into two parts: a first part that can do all the calculations on a certain cell without taking care of other threads, and a second part (which is writing the local data into the global matrices and vectors) which can be entered by only one thread at a time. In order to implement that, we provide functions for each of those two steps for all the four assembly routines that we use in this program. The following eight functions do exactly this:
1899 *
1900 
1901 *
1902 * @code
1903  void local_assemble_stokes_preconditioner(
1904  const typename DoFHandler<dim>::active_cell_iterator &cell,
1905  Assembly::Scratch::StokesPreconditioner<dim> & scratch,
1906  Assembly::CopyData::StokesPreconditioner<dim> & data);
1907 *
1908  void copy_local_to_global_stokes_preconditioner(
1909  const Assembly::CopyData::StokesPreconditioner<dim> &data);
1910 *
1911 
1912  void local_assemble_stokes_system(
1913  const typename DoFHandler<dim>::active_cell_iterator &cell,
1914  Assembly::Scratch::StokesSystem<dim> & scratch,
1915  Assembly::CopyData::StokesSystem<dim> & data);
1916 *
1917  void copy_local_to_global_stokes_system(
1918  const Assembly::CopyData::StokesSystem<dim> &data);
1919 *
1920 
1921  void local_assemble_temperature_matrix(
1922  const typename DoFHandler<dim>::active_cell_iterator &cell,
1923  Assembly::Scratch::TemperatureMatrix<dim> & scratch,
1924  Assembly::CopyData::TemperatureMatrix<dim> & data);
1925 *
1926  void copy_local_to_global_temperature_matrix(
1927  const Assembly::CopyData::TemperatureMatrix<dim> &data);
1928 *
1929 
1930 *
1931  void local_assemble_temperature_rhs(
1932  const std::pair<double, double> global_T_range,
1933  const double global_max_velocity,
1934  const double global_entropy_variation,
1935  const typename DoFHandler<dim>::active_cell_iterator &cell,
1936  Assembly::Scratch::TemperatureRHS<dim> & scratch,
1937  Assembly::CopyData::TemperatureRHS<dim> & data);
1938 *
1939  void copy_local_to_global_temperature_rhs(
1940  const Assembly::CopyData::TemperatureRHS<dim> &data);
1941 *
1942  @endcode
1943 *
1944 * Finally, we forward declare a member class that we will define later on and that will be used to compute a number of quantities from our solution vectors that we'd like to put into the output files for visualization.
1945 *
1946 
1947 *
1948 * @code
1949  class Postprocessor;
1950  };
1951 *
1952 
1953  @endcode
1954 *
1955 * <a name="BoussinesqFlowProblemclassimplementation"></a> <h3>BoussinesqFlowProblem class implementation</h3>
1956 *
1957 
1958 *
1959 * <a name="BoussinesqFlowProblemParameters"></a> <h4>BoussinesqFlowProblem::Parameters</h4>
1960 * Here comes the definition of the parameters for the Stokes problem. We allow to set the end time for the simulation, the level of refinements (both global and adaptive, which in the sum specify what maximum level the cells are allowed to have), and the interval between refinements in the time stepping.
1961 * Then, we let the user specify constants for the stabilization parameters (as discussed in the introduction), the polynomial degree for the Stokes velocity space, whether to use the locally conservative discretization based on FE_DGP elements for the pressure or not (FE_Q elements for pressure), and the polynomial degree for the temperature interpolation.
1962 * The constructor checks for a valid input file (if not, a file with default parameters for the quantities is written), and eventually parses the parameters.
1963 *
1964 
1965 *
1966 * @code
1967  template <int dim>
1968  BoussinesqFlowProblem<dim>::Parameters::Parameters(
1969  const std::string &parameter_filename)
1970  : end_time(1e8)
1971  , initial_global_refinement(2)
1972  , initial_adaptive_refinement(2)
1973  , adaptive_refinement_interval(10)
1974  , stabilization_alpha(2)
1975  , stabilization_c_R(0.11)
1976  , stabilization_beta(0.078)
1977  , stokes_velocity_degree(2)
1978  , use_locally_conservative_discretization(true)
1979  , temperature_degree(2)
1980  {
1981  ParameterHandler prm;
1982  BoussinesqFlowProblem<dim>::Parameters::declare_parameters(prm);
1983 *
1984  std::ifstream parameter_file(parameter_filename);
1985 *
1986  if (!parameter_file)
1987  {
1988  parameter_file.close();
1989 *
1990  std::ofstream parameter_out(parameter_filename);
1991  prm.print_parameters(parameter_out, ParameterHandler::Text);
1992 *
1993  AssertThrow(
1994  false,
1995  ExcMessage(
1996  "Input parameter file <" + parameter_filename +
1997  "> not found. Creating a template file of the same name."));
1998  }
1999 *
2000  prm.parse_input(parameter_file);
2001  parse_parameters(prm);
2002  }
2003 *
2004 
2005 *
2006  @endcode
2007 *
2008 * Next we have a function that declares the parameters that we expect in the input file, together with their data types, default values and a description:
2009 *
2010 
2011 *
2012 * @code
2013  template <int dim>
2014  void BoussinesqFlowProblem<dim>::Parameters::declare_parameters(
2015  ParameterHandler &prm)
2016  {
2017  prm.declare_entry("End time",
2018  "1e8",
2019  Patterns::Double(0),
2020  "The end time of the simulation in years.");
2021  prm.declare_entry("Initial global refinement",
2022  "2",
2023  Patterns::Integer(0),
2024  "The number of global refinement steps performed on "
2025  "the initial coarse mesh, before the problem is first "
2026  "solved there.");
2027  prm.declare_entry("Initial adaptive refinement",
2028  "2",
2029  Patterns::Integer(0),
2030  "The number of adaptive refinement steps performed after "
2031  "initial global refinement.");
2032  prm.declare_entry("Time steps between mesh refinement",
2033  "10",
2034  Patterns::Integer(1),
2035  "The number of time steps after which the mesh is to be "
2036  "adapted based on computed error indicators.");
2037  prm.declare_entry("Generate graphical output",
2038  "false",
2039  Patterns::Bool(),
2040  "Whether graphical output is to be generated or not. "
2041  "You may not want to get graphical output if the number "
2042  "of processors is large.");
2043  prm.declare_entry("Time steps between graphical output",
2044  "50",
2045  Patterns::Integer(1),
2046  "The number of time steps between each generation of "
2047  "graphical output files.");
2048 *
2049  prm.enter_subsection("Stabilization parameters");
2050  {
2051  prm.declare_entry("alpha",
2052  "2",
2053  Patterns::Double(1, 2),
2054  "The exponent in the entropy viscosity stabilization.");
2055  prm.declare_entry("c_R",
2056  "0.11",
2057  Patterns::Double(0),
2058  "The c_R factor in the entropy viscosity "
2059  "stabilization.");
2060  prm.declare_entry("beta",
2061  "0.078",
2062  Patterns::Double(0),
2063  "The beta factor in the artificial viscosity "
2064  "stabilization. An appropriate value for 2d is 0.052 "
2065  "and 0.078 for 3d.");
2066  }
2067  prm.leave_subsection();
2068 *
2069  prm.enter_subsection("Discretization");
2070  {
2071  prm.declare_entry(
2072  "Stokes velocity polynomial degree",
2073  "2",
2074  Patterns::Integer(1),
2075  "The polynomial degree to use for the velocity variables "
2076  "in the Stokes system.");
2077  prm.declare_entry(
2078  "Temperature polynomial degree",
2079  "2",
2080  Patterns::Integer(1),
2081  "The polynomial degree to use for the temperature variable.");
2082  prm.declare_entry(
2083  "Use locally conservative discretization",
2084  "true",
2085  Patterns::Bool(),
2086  "Whether to use a Stokes discretization that is locally "
2087  "conservative at the expense of a larger number of degrees "
2088  "of freedom, or to go with a cheaper discretization "
2089  "that does not locally conserve mass (although it is "
2090  "globally conservative.");
2091  }
2092  prm.leave_subsection();
2093  }
2094 *
2095 
2096 *
2097  @endcode
2098 *
2099 * And then we need a function that reads the contents of the ParameterHandler object we get by reading the input file and puts the results into variables that store the values of the parameters we have previously declared:
2100 *
2101 
2102 *
2103 * @code
2104  template <int dim>
2105  void BoussinesqFlowProblem<dim>::Parameters::parse_parameters(
2106  ParameterHandler &prm)
2107  {
2108  end_time = prm.get_double("End time");
2109  initial_global_refinement = prm.get_integer("Initial global refinement");
2110  initial_adaptive_refinement =
2111  prm.get_integer("Initial adaptive refinement");
2112 *
2113  adaptive_refinement_interval =
2114  prm.get_integer("Time steps between mesh refinement");
2115 *
2116  generate_graphical_output = prm.get_bool("Generate graphical output");
2117  graphical_output_interval =
2118  prm.get_integer("Time steps between graphical output");
2119 *
2120  prm.enter_subsection("Stabilization parameters");
2121  {
2122  stabilization_alpha = prm.get_double("alpha");
2123  stabilization_c_R = prm.get_double("c_R");
2124  stabilization_beta = prm.get_double("beta");
2125  }
2126  prm.leave_subsection();
2127 *
2128  prm.enter_subsection("Discretization");
2129  {
2130  stokes_velocity_degree =
2131  prm.get_integer("Stokes velocity polynomial degree");
2132  temperature_degree = prm.get_integer("Temperature polynomial degree");
2133  use_locally_conservative_discretization =
2134  prm.get_bool("Use locally conservative discretization");
2135  }
2136  prm.leave_subsection();
2137  }
2138 *
2139 
2140 *
2141  @endcode
2142 *
2143 * <a name="BoussinesqFlowProblemBoussinesqFlowProblem"></a> <h4>BoussinesqFlowProblem::BoussinesqFlowProblem</h4>
2144 * The constructor of the problem is very similar to the constructor in @ref step_31 "step-31" . What is different is the %parallel communication: Trilinos uses a message passing interface (MPI) for data distribution. When entering the BoussinesqFlowProblem class, we have to decide how the parallelization is to be done. We choose a rather simple strategy and let all processors that are running the program work together, specified by the communicator <code>MPI_COMM_WORLD</code> . Next, we create the output stream (as we already did in @ref step_18 "step-18" ) that only generates output on the first MPI process and is completely forgetful on all others. The implementation of this idea is to check the process number when <code>pcout</code> gets a true argument, and it uses the <code>std::cout</code> stream for output. If we are one processor five, for instance, then we will give a <code>false</code> argument to <code>pcout</code> , which means that the output of that processor will not be printed. With the exception of the mapping object (for which we use polynomials of degree 4) all but the final member variable are exactly the same as in @ref step_31 "step-31" .
2145 * This final object, the TimerOutput object, is then told to restrict output to the <code>pcout</code> stream (processor 0), and then we specify that we want to get a summary table at the end of the program which shows us wallclock times (as opposed to CPU times). We will manually also request intermediate summaries every so many time steps in the <code>run()</code> function below.
2146 *
2147 
2148 *
2149 * @code
2150  template <int dim>
2151  BoussinesqFlowProblem<dim>::BoussinesqFlowProblem(Parameters &parameters_)
2152  : parameters(parameters_)
2153  , pcout(std::cout, (Utilities::MPI::this_mpi_process(MPI_COMM_WORLD) == 0))
2154  ,
2155 *
2156  triangulation(MPI_COMM_WORLD,
2157  typename Triangulation<dim>::MeshSmoothing(
2158  Triangulation<dim>::smoothing_on_refinement |
2159  Triangulation<dim>::smoothing_on_coarsening))
2160  ,
2161 *
2162  global_Omega_diameter(0.)
2163  ,
2164 *
2165  mapping(4)
2166  ,
2167 *
2168  stokes_fe(FE_Q<dim>(parameters.stokes_velocity_degree),
2169  dim,
2170  (parameters.use_locally_conservative_discretization ?
2171  static_cast<const FiniteElement<dim> &>(
2172  FE_DGP<dim>(parameters.stokes_velocity_degree
2173 *
2174 - 1)) :
2175  static_cast<const FiniteElement<dim> &>(
2176  FE_Q<dim>(parameters.stokes_velocity_degree
2177 *
2178 - 1))),
2179  1)
2180  ,
2181 *
2182  stokes_dof_handler(triangulation)
2183  ,
2184 *
2185  temperature_fe(parameters.temperature_degree)
2186  , temperature_dof_handler(triangulation)
2187  ,
2188 *
2189  time_step(0)
2190  , old_time_step(0)
2191  , timestep_number(0)
2192  , rebuild_stokes_matrix(true)
2193  , rebuild_stokes_preconditioner(true)
2194  , rebuild_temperature_matrices(true)
2195  , rebuild_temperature_preconditioner(true)
2196  ,
2197 *
2198  computing_timer(MPI_COMM_WORLD,
2199  pcout,
2200  TimerOutput::summary,
2201  TimerOutput::wall_times)
2202  {}
2203 *
2204 
2205 *
2206  @endcode
2207 *
2208 * <a name="TheBoussinesqFlowProblemhelperfunctions"></a> <h4>The BoussinesqFlowProblem helper functions</h4>
2209 * <a name="BoussinesqFlowProblemget_maximal_velocity"></a> <h5>BoussinesqFlowProblem::get_maximal_velocity</h5>
2210 *
2211 
2212 *
2213 * Except for two small details, the function to compute the global maximum of the velocity is the same as in @ref step_31 "step-31" . The first detail is actually common to all functions that implement loops over all cells in the triangulation: When operating in %parallel, each processor can only work on a chunk of cells since each processor only has a certain part of the entire triangulation. This chunk of cells that we want to work on is identified via a so-called <code>subdomain_id</code> , as we also did in @ref step_18 "step-18" . All we need to change is hence to perform the cell-related operations only on cells that are owned by the current process (as opposed to ghost or artificial cells), i.e. for which the subdomain id equals the number of the process ID. Since this is a commonly used operation, there is a shortcut for this operation: we can ask whether the cell is owned by the current processor using <code>cell-@>is_locally_owned()</code> .
2214 * The second difference is the way we calculate the maximum value. Before, we could simply have a <code>double</code> variable that we checked against on each quadrature point for each cell. Now, we have to be a bit more careful since each processor only operates on a subset of cells. What we do is to first let each processor calculate the maximum among its cells, and then do a global communication operation <code>Utilities::MPI::max</code> that computes the maximum value among all the maximum values of the individual processors. MPI provides such a call, but it's even simpler to use the respective function in namespace Utilities::MPI using the MPI communicator object since that will do the right thing even if we work without MPI and on a single machine only. The call to <code>Utilities::MPI::max</code> needs two arguments, namely the local maximum (input) and the MPI communicator, which is MPI_COMM_WORLD in this example.
2215 *
2216 
2217 *
2218 * @code
2219  template <int dim>
2220  double BoussinesqFlowProblem<dim>::get_maximal_velocity() const
2221  {
2222  const QIterated<dim> quadrature_formula(QTrapezoid<1>(),
2223  parameters.stokes_velocity_degree);
2224  const unsigned int n_q_points = quadrature_formula.size();
2225 *
2226  FEValues<dim> fe_values(mapping,
2227  stokes_fe,
2228  quadrature_formula,
2229  update_values);
2230  std::vector<Tensor<1, dim>> velocity_values(n_q_points);
2231 *
2232  const FEValuesExtractors::Vector velocities(0);
2233 *
2234  double max_local_velocity = 0;
2235 *
2236  for (const auto &cell : stokes_dof_handler.active_cell_iterators())
2237  if (cell->is_locally_owned())
2238  {
2239  fe_values.reinit(cell);
2240  fe_values[velocities].get_function_values(stokes_solution,
2241  velocity_values);
2242 *
2243  for (unsigned int q = 0; q < n_q_points; ++q)
2244  max_local_velocity =
2245  std::max(max_local_velocity, velocity_values[q].norm());
2246  }
2247 *
2248  return Utilities::MPI::max(max_local_velocity, MPI_COMM_WORLD);
2249  }
2250 *
2251 
2252  @endcode
2253 *
2254 * <a name="BoussinesqFlowProblemget_cfl_number"></a> <h5>BoussinesqFlowProblem::get_cfl_number</h5>
2255 *
2256 
2257 *
2258 * The next function does something similar, but we now compute the CFL number, i.e., maximal velocity on a cell divided by the cell diameter. This number is necessary to determine the time step size, as we use a semi-explicit time stepping scheme for the temperature equation (see @ref step_31 "step-31" for a discussion). We compute it in the same way as above: Compute the local maximum over all locally owned cells, then exchange it via MPI to find the global maximum.
2259 *
2260 
2261 *
2262 * @code
2263  template <int dim>
2264  double BoussinesqFlowProblem<dim>::get_cfl_number() const
2265  {
2266  const QIterated<dim> quadrature_formula(QTrapezoid<1>(),
2267  parameters.stokes_velocity_degree);
2268  const unsigned int n_q_points = quadrature_formula.size();
2269 *
2270  FEValues<dim> fe_values(mapping,
2271  stokes_fe,
2272  quadrature_formula,
2273  update_values);
2274  std::vector<Tensor<1, dim>> velocity_values(n_q_points);
2275 *
2276  const FEValuesExtractors::Vector velocities(0);
2277 *
2278  double max_local_cfl = 0;
2279 *
2280  for (const auto &cell : stokes_dof_handler.active_cell_iterators())
2281  if (cell->is_locally_owned())
2282  {
2283  fe_values.reinit(cell);
2284  fe_values[velocities].get_function_values(stokes_solution,
2285  velocity_values);
2286 *
2287  double max_local_velocity = 1e-10;
2288  for (unsigned int q = 0; q < n_q_points; ++q)
2289  max_local_velocity =
2290  std::max(max_local_velocity, velocity_values[q].norm());
2291  max_local_cfl =
2292  std::max(max_local_cfl, max_local_velocity / cell->diameter());
2293  }
2294 *
2295  return Utilities::MPI::max(max_local_cfl, MPI_COMM_WORLD);
2296  }
2297 *
2298 
2299  @endcode
2300 *
2301 * <a name="BoussinesqFlowProblemget_entropy_variation"></a> <h5>BoussinesqFlowProblem::get_entropy_variation</h5>
2302 *
2303 
2304 *
2305 * Next comes the computation of the global entropy variation @f$\|E(T)-\bar{E}(T)\|_\infty@f$ where the entropy @f$E@f$ is defined as discussed in the introduction. This is needed for the evaluation of the stabilization in the temperature equation as explained in the introduction. The entropy variation is actually only needed if we use @f$\alpha=2@f$ as a power in the residual computation. The infinity norm is computed by the maxima over quadrature points, as usual in discrete computations.
2306 * In order to compute this quantity, we first have to find the space-average @f$\bar{E}(T)@f$ and then evaluate the maximum. However, that means that we would need to perform two loops. We can avoid the overhead by noting that @f$\|E(T)-\bar{E}(T)\|_\infty =
2307  \max\big(E_{\textrm{max}}(T)-\bar{E}(T),
2308  \bar{E}(T)-E_{\textrm{min}}(T)\big)@f$ , i.e., the maximum out of the deviation from the average entropy in positive and negative directions. The four quantities we need for the latter formula (maximum entropy, minimum entropy, average entropy, area) can all be evaluated in the same loop over all cells, so we choose this simpler variant.
2309 *
2310 
2311 *
2312 * @code
2313  template <int dim>
2314  double BoussinesqFlowProblem<dim>::get_entropy_variation(
2315  const double average_temperature) const
2316  {
2317  if (parameters.stabilization_alpha != 2)
2318  return 1.;
2319 *
2320  const QGauss<dim> quadrature_formula(parameters.temperature_degree + 1);
2321  const unsigned int n_q_points = quadrature_formula.size();
2322 *
2323  FEValues<dim> fe_values(temperature_fe,
2324  quadrature_formula,
2325  update_values | update_JxW_values);
2326  std::vector<double> old_temperature_values(n_q_points);
2327  std::vector<double> old_old_temperature_values(n_q_points);
2328 *
2329  @endcode
2330 *
2331 * In the two functions above we computed the maximum of numbers that were all non-negative, so we knew that zero was certainly a lower bound. On the other hand, here we need to find the maximum deviation from the average value, i.e., we will need to know the maximal and minimal values of the entropy for which we don't a priori know the sign.
2332 * To compute it, we can therefore start with the largest and smallest possible values we can store in a double precision number: The minimum is initialized with a bigger and the maximum with a smaller number than any one that is going to appear. We are then guaranteed that these numbers will be overwritten in the loop on the first cell or, if this processor does not own any cells, in the communication step at the latest. The following loop then computes the minimum and maximum local entropy as well as keeps track of the area/volume of the part of the domain we locally own and the integral over the entropy on it:
2333 *
2334 
2335 *
2336 * @code
2337  double min_entropy = std::numeric_limits<double>::max(),
2338  max_entropy =
2339 *
2340 -std::numeric_limits<double>::max(), area = 0,
2341  entropy_integrated = 0;
2342 *
2343  for (const auto &cell : temperature_dof_handler.active_cell_iterators())
2344  if (cell->is_locally_owned())
2345  {
2346  fe_values.reinit(cell);
2347  fe_values.get_function_values(old_temperature_solution,
2348  old_temperature_values);
2349  fe_values.get_function_values(old_old_temperature_solution,
2350  old_old_temperature_values);
2351  for (unsigned int q = 0; q < n_q_points; ++q)
2352  {
2353  const double T =
2354  (old_temperature_values[q] + old_old_temperature_values[q]) / 2;
2355  const double entropy =
2356  ((T
2357 *
2358 - average_temperature) (T
2359 *
2360 - average_temperature));
2361 *
2362  min_entropy = std::min(min_entropy, entropy);
2363  max_entropy = std::max(max_entropy, entropy);
2364  area += fe_values.JxW(q);
2365  entropy_integrated += fe_values.JxW(q) entropy;
2366  }
2367  }
2368 *
2369  @endcode
2370 *
2371 * Now we only need to exchange data between processors: we need to sum the two integrals ( <code>area</code>, <code>entropy_integrated</code> ), and get the extrema for maximum and minimum. We could do this through four different data exchanges, but we can it with two: Utilities::MPI::sum also exists in a variant that takes an array of values that are all to be summed up. And we can also utilize the Utilities::MPI::max function by realizing that forming the minimum over the minimal entropies equals forming the negative of the maximum over the negative of the minimal entropies; this maximum can then be combined with forming the maximum over the maximal entropies.
2372 *
2373 
2374 *
2375 * @code
2376  const double local_sums[2] = {entropy_integrated, area},
2377  local_maxima[2] = {-min_entropy, max_entropy};
2378  double global_sums[2], global_maxima[2];
2379 *
2380  Utilities::MPI::sum(local_sums, MPI_COMM_WORLD, global_sums);
2381  Utilities::MPI::max(local_maxima, MPI_COMM_WORLD, global_maxima);
2382 *
2383  @endcode
2384 *
2385 * Having computed everything this way, we can then compute the average entropy and find the @f$L^\infty@f$ norm by taking the larger of the deviation of the maximum or minimum from the average:
2386 *
2387 
2388 *
2389 * @code
2390  const double average_entropy = global_sums[0] / global_sums[1];
2391  const double entropy_diff = std::max(global_maxima[1]
2392 *
2393 - average_entropy,
2394  average_entropy
2395 *
2396 - (-global_maxima[0]));
2397  return entropy_diff;
2398  }
2399 *
2400 
2401 *
2402  @endcode
2403 *
2404 * <a name="BoussinesqFlowProblemget_extrapolated_temperature_range"></a> <h5>BoussinesqFlowProblem::get_extrapolated_temperature_range</h5>
2405 *
2406 
2407 *
2408 * The next function computes the minimal and maximal value of the extrapolated temperature over the entire domain. Again, this is only a slightly modified version of the respective function in @ref step_31 "step-31" . As in the function above, we collect local minima and maxima and then compute the global extrema using the same trick as above.
2409 * As already discussed in @ref step_31 "step-31" , the function needs to distinguish between the first and all following time steps because it uses a higher order temperature extrapolation scheme when at least two previous time steps are available.
2410 *
2411 
2412 *
2413 * @code
2414  template <int dim>
2415  std::pair<double, double>
2416  BoussinesqFlowProblem<dim>::get_extrapolated_temperature_range() const
2417  {
2418  const QIterated<dim> quadrature_formula(QTrapezoid<1>(),
2419  parameters.temperature_degree);
2420  const unsigned int n_q_points = quadrature_formula.size();
2421 *
2422  FEValues<dim> fe_values(mapping,
2423  temperature_fe,
2424  quadrature_formula,
2425  update_values);
2426  std::vector<double> old_temperature_values(n_q_points);
2427  std::vector<double> old_old_temperature_values(n_q_points);
2428 *
2429  double min_local_temperature = std::numeric_limits<double>::max(),
2430  max_local_temperature =
2431 *
2432 -std::numeric_limits<double>::max();
2433 *
2434  if (timestep_number != 0)
2435  {
2436  for (const auto &cell : temperature_dof_handler.active_cell_iterators())
2437  if (cell->is_locally_owned())
2438  {
2439  fe_values.reinit(cell);
2440  fe_values.get_function_values(old_temperature_solution,
2441  old_temperature_values);
2442  fe_values.get_function_values(old_old_temperature_solution,
2443  old_old_temperature_values);
2444 *
2445  for (unsigned int q = 0; q < n_q_points; ++q)
2446  {
2447  const double temperature =
2448  (1. + time_step / old_time_step)
2449  old_temperature_values[q]
2450 *
2451 -
2452  time_step / old_time_step old_old_temperature_values[q];
2453 *
2454  min_local_temperature =
2455  std::min(min_local_temperature, temperature);
2456  max_local_temperature =
2457  std::max(max_local_temperature, temperature);
2458  }
2459  }
2460  }
2461  else
2462  {
2463  for (const auto &cell : temperature_dof_handler.active_cell_iterators())
2464  if (cell->is_locally_owned())
2465  {
2466  fe_values.reinit(cell);
2467  fe_values.get_function_values(old_temperature_solution,
2468  old_temperature_values);
2469 *
2470  for (unsigned int q = 0; q < n_q_points; ++q)
2471  {
2472  const double temperature = old_temperature_values[q];
2473 *
2474  min_local_temperature =
2475  std::min(min_local_temperature, temperature);
2476  max_local_temperature =
2477  std::max(max_local_temperature, temperature);
2478  }
2479  }
2480  }
2481 *
2482  double local_extrema[2] = {-min_local_temperature, max_local_temperature};
2483  double global_extrema[2];
2484  Utilities::MPI::max(local_extrema, MPI_COMM_WORLD, global_extrema);
2485 *
2486  return std::make_pair(-global_extrema[0], global_extrema[1]);
2487  }
2488 *
2489 
2490  @endcode
2491 *
2492 * <a name="BoussinesqFlowProblemcompute_viscosity"></a> <h5>BoussinesqFlowProblem::compute_viscosity</h5>
2493 *
2494 
2495 *
2496 * The function that calculates the viscosity is purely local and so needs no communication at all. It is mostly the same as in @ref step_31 "step-31" but with an updated formulation of the viscosity if @f$\alpha=2@f$ is chosen:
2497 *
2498 
2499 *
2500 * @code
2501  template <int dim>
2502  double BoussinesqFlowProblem<dim>::compute_viscosity(
2503  const std::vector<double> & old_temperature,
2504  const std::vector<double> & old_old_temperature,
2505  const std::vector<Tensor<1, dim>> & old_temperature_grads,
2506  const std::vector<Tensor<1, dim>> & old_old_temperature_grads,
2507  const std::vector<double> & old_temperature_laplacians,
2508  const std::vector<double> & old_old_temperature_laplacians,
2509  const std::vector<Tensor<1, dim>> & old_velocity_values,
2510  const std::vector<Tensor<1, dim>> & old_old_velocity_values,
2511  const std::vector<SymmetricTensor<2, dim>> &old_strain_rates,
2512  const std::vector<SymmetricTensor<2, dim>> &old_old_strain_rates,
2513  const double global_u_infty,
2514  const double global_T_variation,
2515  const double average_temperature,
2516  const double global_entropy_variation,
2517  const double cell_diameter) const
2518  {
2519  if (global_u_infty == 0)
2520  return 5e-3 cell_diameter;
2521 *
2522  const unsigned int n_q_points = old_temperature.size();
2523 *
2524  double max_residual = 0;
2525  double max_velocity = 0;
2526 *
2527  for (unsigned int q = 0; q < n_q_points; ++q)
2528  {
2529  const Tensor<1, dim> u =
2530  (old_velocity_values[q] + old_old_velocity_values[q]) / 2;
2531 *
2532  const SymmetricTensor<2, dim> strain_rate =
2533  (old_strain_rates[q] + old_old_strain_rates[q]) / 2;
2534 *
2535  const double T = (old_temperature[q] + old_old_temperature[q]) / 2;
2536  const double dT_dt =
2537  (old_temperature[q]
2538 *
2539 - old_old_temperature[q]) / old_time_step;
2540  const double u_grad_T =
2541  u (old_temperature_grads[q] + old_old_temperature_grads[q]) / 2;
2542 *
2543  const double kappa_Delta_T =
2544  EquationData::kappa
2545  (old_temperature_laplacians[q] + old_old_temperature_laplacians[q]) /
2546  2;
2547  const double gamma =
2548  ((EquationData::radiogenic_heating EquationData::density(T) +
2549  2 EquationData::eta strain_rate strain_rate) /
2550  (EquationData::density(T) EquationData::specific_heat));
2551 *
2552  double residual = std::abs(dT_dt + u_grad_T
2553 *
2554 - kappa_Delta_T
2555 *
2556 - gamma);
2557  if (parameters.stabilization_alpha == 2)
2558  residual= std::abs(T
2559 *
2560 - average_temperature);
2561 *
2562  max_residual = std::max(residual, max_residual);
2563  max_velocity = std::max(std::sqrt(u u), max_velocity);
2564  }
2565 *
2566  const double max_viscosity =
2567  (parameters.stabilization_beta max_velocity cell_diameter);
2568  if (timestep_number == 0)
2569  return max_viscosity;
2570  else
2571  {
2572  Assert(old_time_step > 0, ExcInternalError());
2573 *
2574  double entropy_viscosity;
2575  if (parameters.stabilization_alpha == 2)
2576  entropy_viscosity =
2577  (parameters.stabilization_c_R cell_diameter cell_diameter
2578  max_residual / global_entropy_variation);
2579  else
2580  entropy_viscosity =
2581  (parameters.stabilization_c_R cell_diameter
2582  global_Omega_diameter max_velocity max_residual /
2583  (global_u_infty global_T_variation));
2584 *
2585  return std::min(max_viscosity, entropy_viscosity);
2586  }
2587  }
2588 *
2589 
2590 *
2591  @endcode
2592 *
2593 * <a name="TheBoussinesqFlowProblemsetupfunctions"></a> <h4>The BoussinesqFlowProblem setup functions</h4>
2594 *
2595 
2596 *
2597 * The following three functions set up the Stokes matrix, the matrix used for the Stokes preconditioner, and the temperature matrix. The code is mostly the same as in @ref step_31 "step-31" , but it has been broken out into three functions of their own for simplicity.
2598 * The main functional difference between the code here and that in @ref step_31 "step-31" is that the matrices we want to set up are distributed across multiple processors. Since we still want to build up the sparsity pattern first for efficiency reasons, we could continue to build the <i>entire</i> sparsity pattern as a BlockDynamicSparsityPattern, as we did in @ref step_31 "step-31" . However, that would be inefficient: every processor would build the same sparsity pattern, but only initialize a small part of the matrix using it. It also violates the principle that every processor should only work on those cells it owns (and, if necessary the layer of ghost cells around it).
2599 * Rather, we use an object of type TrilinosWrappers::BlockSparsityPattern, which is (obviously) a wrapper around a sparsity pattern object provided by Trilinos. The advantage is that the Trilinos sparsity pattern class can communicate across multiple processors: if this processor fills in all the nonzero entries that result from the cells it owns, and every other processor does so as well, then at the end after some MPI communication initiated by the <code>compress()</code> call, we will have the globally assembled sparsity pattern available with which the global matrix can be initialized.
2600 * There is one important aspect when initializing Trilinos sparsity patterns in parallel: In addition to specifying the locally owned rows and columns of the matrices via the @p stokes_partitioning index set, we also supply information about all the rows we are possibly going to write into when assembling on a certain processor. The set of locally relevant rows contains all such rows (possibly also a few unnecessary ones, but it is difficult to find the exact row indices before actually getting indices on all cells and resolving constraints). This additional information allows to exactly determine the structure for the off-processor data found during assembly. While Trilinos matrices are able to collect this information on the fly as well (when initializing them from some other reinit method), it is less efficient and leads to problems when assembling matrices with multiple threads. In this program, we pessimistically assume that only one processor at a time can write into the matrix while assembly (whereas the computation is parallel), which is fine for Trilinos matrices. In practice, one can do better by hinting WorkStream at cells that do not share vertices, allowing for parallelism among those cells (see the graph coloring algorithms and WorkStream with colored iterators argument). However, that only works when only one MPI processor is present because Trilinos' internal data structures for accumulating off-processor data on the fly are not thread safe. With the initialization presented here, there is no such problem and one could safely introduce graph coloring for this algorithm.
2601 * The only other change we need to make is to tell the DoFTools::make_sparsity_pattern() function that it is only supposed to work on a subset of cells, namely the ones whose <code>subdomain_id</code> equals the number of the current processor, and to ignore all other cells.
2602 * This strategy is replicated across all three of the following functions.
2603 * Note that Trilinos matrices store the information contained in the sparsity patterns, so we can safely release the <code>sp</code> variable once the matrix has been given the sparsity structure.
2604 *
2605 
2606 *
2607 * @code
2608  template <int dim>
2609  void BoussinesqFlowProblem<dim>::setup_stokes_matrix(
2610  const std::vector<IndexSet> &stokes_partitioning,
2611  const std::vector<IndexSet> &stokes_relevant_partitioning)
2612  {
2613  stokes_matrix.clear();
2614 *
2615  TrilinosWrappers::BlockSparsityPattern sp(stokes_partitioning,
2616  stokes_partitioning,
2617  stokes_relevant_partitioning,
2618  MPI_COMM_WORLD);
2619 *
2620  Table<2, DoFTools::Coupling> coupling(dim + 1, dim + 1);
2621  for (unsigned int c = 0; c < dim + 1; ++c)
2622  for (unsigned int d = 0; d < dim + 1; ++d)
2623  if (!((c == dim) && (d == dim)))
2624  coupling[c][d] = DoFTools::always;
2625  else
2626  coupling[c][d] = DoFTools::none;
2627 *
2628  DoFTools::make_sparsity_pattern(stokes_dof_handler,
2629  coupling,
2630  sp,
2631  stokes_constraints,
2632  false,
2633  Utilities::MPI::this_mpi_process(
2634  MPI_COMM_WORLD));
2635  sp.compress();
2636 *
2637  stokes_matrix.reinit(sp);
2638  }
2639 *
2640 
2641 *
2642  template <int dim>
2643  void BoussinesqFlowProblem<dim>::setup_stokes_preconditioner(
2644  const std::vector<IndexSet> &stokes_partitioning,
2645  const std::vector<IndexSet> &stokes_relevant_partitioning)
2646  {
2647  Amg_preconditioner.reset();
2648  Mp_preconditioner.reset();
2649 *
2650  stokes_preconditioner_matrix.clear();
2651 *
2652  TrilinosWrappers::BlockSparsityPattern sp(stokes_partitioning,
2653  stokes_partitioning,
2654  stokes_relevant_partitioning,
2655  MPI_COMM_WORLD);
2656 *
2657  Table<2, DoFTools::Coupling> coupling(dim + 1, dim + 1);
2658  for (unsigned int c = 0; c < dim + 1; ++c)
2659  for (unsigned int d = 0; d < dim + 1; ++d)
2660  if (c == d)
2661  coupling[c][d] = DoFTools::always;
2662  else
2663  coupling[c][d] = DoFTools::none;
2664 *
2665  DoFTools::make_sparsity_pattern(stokes_dof_handler,
2666  coupling,
2667  sp,
2668  stokes_constraints,
2669  false,
2670  Utilities::MPI::this_mpi_process(
2671  MPI_COMM_WORLD));
2672  sp.compress();
2673 *
2674  stokes_preconditioner_matrix.reinit(sp);
2675  }
2676 *
2677 
2678  template <int dim>
2679  void BoussinesqFlowProblem<dim>::setup_temperature_matrices(
2680  const IndexSet &temperature_partitioner,
2681  const IndexSet &temperature_relevant_partitioner)
2682  {
2683  T_preconditioner.reset();
2684  temperature_mass_matrix.clear();
2685  temperature_stiffness_matrix.clear();
2686  temperature_matrix.clear();
2687 *
2688  TrilinosWrappers::SparsityPattern sp(temperature_partitioner,
2689  temperature_partitioner,
2690  temperature_relevant_partitioner,
2691  MPI_COMM_WORLD);
2692  DoFTools::make_sparsity_pattern(temperature_dof_handler,
2693  sp,
2694  temperature_constraints,
2695  false,
2696  Utilities::MPI::this_mpi_process(
2697  MPI_COMM_WORLD));
2698  sp.compress();
2699 *
2700  temperature_matrix.reinit(sp);
2701  temperature_mass_matrix.reinit(sp);
2702  temperature_stiffness_matrix.reinit(sp);
2703  }
2704 *
2705 
2706 *
2707  @endcode
2708 *
2709 * The remainder of the setup function (after splitting out the three functions above) mostly has to deal with the things we need to do for parallelization across processors. Because setting all of this up is a significant compute time expense of the program, we put everything we do here into a timer group so that we can get summary information about the fraction of time spent in this part of the program at its end.
2710 * At the top as usual we enumerate degrees of freedom and sort them by component/block, followed by writing their numbers to the screen from processor zero. The DoFHandler::distributed_dofs() function, when applied to a parallel::distributed::Triangulation object, sorts degrees of freedom in such a way that all degrees of freedom associated with subdomain zero come before all those associated with subdomain one, etc. For the Stokes part, this entails, however, that velocities and pressures become intermixed, but this is trivially solved by sorting again by blocks; it is worth noting that this latter operation leaves the relative ordering of all velocities and pressures alone, i.e. within the velocity block we will still have all those associated with subdomain zero before all velocities associated with subdomain one, etc. This is important since we store each of the blocks of this matrix distributed across all processors and want this to be done in such a way that each processor stores that part of the matrix that is roughly equal to the degrees of freedom located on those cells that it will actually work on.
2711 * When printing the numbers of degrees of freedom, note that these numbers are going to be large if we use many processors. Consequently, we let the stream put a comma separator in between every three digits. The state of the stream, using the locale, is saved from before to after this operation. While slightly opaque, the code works because the default locale (which we get using the constructor call <code>std::locale("")</code> ) implies printing numbers with a comma separator for every third digit (i.e., thousands, millions, billions).
2712 * In this function as well as many below, we measure how much time we spend here and collect that in a section called "Setup dof systems" across function invocations. This is done using an TimerOutput::Scope object that gets a timer going in the section with above name of the `computing_timer` object upon construction of the local variable; the timer is stopped again when the destructor of the `timing_section` variable is called. This, of course, happens either at the end of the function, or if we leave the function through a `return` statement or when an exception is thrown somewhere
2713 *
2714 * - in other words, whenever we leave this function in any way. The use of such "scope" objects therefore makes sure that we do not have to manually add code that tells the timer to stop at every location where this function may be left.
2715 *
2716 
2717 *
2718 * @code
2719  template <int dim>
2720  void BoussinesqFlowProblem<dim>::setup_dofs()
2721  {
2722  TimerOutput::Scope timing_section(computing_timer, "Setup dof systems");
2723 *
2724  stokes_dof_handler.distribute_dofs(stokes_fe);
2725 *
2726  std::vector<unsigned int> stokes_sub_blocks(dim + 1, 0);
2727  stokes_sub_blocks[dim] = 1;
2728  DoFRenumbering::component_wise(stokes_dof_handler, stokes_sub_blocks);
2729 *
2730  temperature_dof_handler.distribute_dofs(temperature_fe);
2731 *
2732  const std::vector<types::global_dof_index> stokes_dofs_per_block =
2733  DoFTools::count_dofs_per_fe_block(stokes_dof_handler, stokes_sub_blocks);
2734 *
2735  const unsigned int n_u = stokes_dofs_per_block[0],
2736  n_p = stokes_dofs_per_block[1],
2737  n_T = temperature_dof_handler.n_dofs();
2738 *
2739  std::locale s = pcout.get_stream().getloc();
2740  pcout.get_stream().imbue(std::locale(""));
2741  pcout << "Number of active cells: " << triangulation.n_global_active_cells()
2742  << " (on " << triangulation.n_levels() << " levels)" << std::endl
2743  << "Number of degrees of freedom: " << n_u + n_p + n_T << " (" << n_u
2744  << '+' << n_p << '+' << n_T << ')' << std::endl
2745  << std::endl;
2746  pcout.get_stream().imbue(s);
2747 *
2748 
2749  @endcode
2750 *
2751 * After this, we have to set up the various partitioners (of type <code>IndexSet</code> , see the introduction) that describe which parts of each matrix or vector will be stored where, then call the functions that actually set up the matrices, and at the end also resize the various vectors we keep around in this program.
2752 *
2753 
2754 *
2755 * @code
2756  std::vector<IndexSet> stokes_partitioning, stokes_relevant_partitioning;
2757  IndexSet temperature_partitioning(n_T),
2758  temperature_relevant_partitioning(n_T);
2759  IndexSet stokes_relevant_set;
2760  {
2761  IndexSet stokes_index_set = stokes_dof_handler.locally_owned_dofs();
2762  stokes_partitioning.push_back(stokes_index_set.get_view(0, n_u));
2763  stokes_partitioning.push_back(stokes_index_set.get_view(n_u, n_u + n_p));
2764 *
2765  DoFTools::extract_locally_relevant_dofs(stokes_dof_handler,
2766  stokes_relevant_set);
2767  stokes_relevant_partitioning.push_back(
2768  stokes_relevant_set.get_view(0, n_u));
2769  stokes_relevant_partitioning.push_back(
2770  stokes_relevant_set.get_view(n_u, n_u + n_p));
2771 *
2772  temperature_partitioning = temperature_dof_handler.locally_owned_dofs();
2773  DoFTools::extract_locally_relevant_dofs(
2774  temperature_dof_handler, temperature_relevant_partitioning);
2775  }
2776 *
2777  @endcode
2778 *
2779 * Following this, we can compute constraints for the solution vectors, including hanging node constraints and homogeneous and inhomogeneous boundary values for the Stokes and temperature fields. Note that as for everything else, the constraint objects can not hold <i>all</i> constraints on every processor. Rather, each processor needs to store only those that are actually necessary for correctness given that it only assembles linear systems on cells it owns. As discussed in the @ref distributed_paper "this paper", the set of constraints we need to know about is exactly the set of constraints on all locally relevant degrees of freedom, so this is what we use to initialize the constraint objects.
2780 *
2781 
2782 *
2783 * @code
2784  {
2785  stokes_constraints.clear();
2786  stokes_constraints.reinit(stokes_relevant_set);
2787 *
2788  DoFTools::make_hanging_node_constraints(stokes_dof_handler,
2789  stokes_constraints);
2790 *
2791  FEValuesExtractors::Vector velocity_components(0);
2792  VectorTools::interpolate_boundary_values(
2793  stokes_dof_handler,
2794  0,
2795  Functions::ZeroFunction<dim>(dim + 1),
2796  stokes_constraints,
2797  stokes_fe.component_mask(velocity_components));
2798 *
2799  std::set<types::boundary_id> no_normal_flux_boundaries;
2800  no_normal_flux_boundaries.insert(1);
2801  VectorTools::compute_no_normal_flux_constraints(stokes_dof_handler,
2802  0,
2803  no_normal_flux_boundaries,
2804  stokes_constraints,
2805  mapping);
2806  stokes_constraints.close();
2807  }
2808  {
2809  temperature_constraints.clear();
2810  temperature_constraints.reinit(temperature_relevant_partitioning);
2811 *
2812  DoFTools::make_hanging_node_constraints(temperature_dof_handler,
2813  temperature_constraints);
2814  VectorTools::interpolate_boundary_values(
2815  temperature_dof_handler,
2816  0,
2817  EquationData::TemperatureInitialValues<dim>(),
2818  temperature_constraints);
2819  VectorTools::interpolate_boundary_values(
2820  temperature_dof_handler,
2821  1,
2822  EquationData::TemperatureInitialValues<dim>(),
2823  temperature_constraints);
2824  temperature_constraints.close();
2825  }
2826 *
2827  @endcode
2828 *
2829 * All this done, we can then initialize the various matrix and vector objects to their proper sizes. At the end, we also record that all matrices and preconditioners have to be re-computed at the beginning of the next time step. Note how we initialize the vectors for the Stokes and temperature right hand sides: These are writable vectors (last boolean argument set to @p true) that have the correct one-to-one partitioning of locally owned elements but are still given the relevant partitioning for means of figuring out the vector entries that are going to be set right away. As for matrices, this allows for writing local contributions into the vector with multiple threads (always assuming that the same vector entry is not accessed by multiple threads at the same time). The other vectors only allow for read access of individual elements, including ghosts, but are not suitable for solvers.
2830 *
2831 
2832 *
2833 * @code
2834  setup_stokes_matrix(stokes_partitioning, stokes_relevant_partitioning);
2835  setup_stokes_preconditioner(stokes_partitioning,
2836  stokes_relevant_partitioning);
2837  setup_temperature_matrices(temperature_partitioning,
2838  temperature_relevant_partitioning);
2839 *
2840  stokes_rhs.reinit(stokes_partitioning,
2841  stokes_relevant_partitioning,
2842  MPI_COMM_WORLD,
2843  true);
2844  stokes_solution.reinit(stokes_relevant_partitioning, MPI_COMM_WORLD);
2845  old_stokes_solution.reinit(stokes_solution);
2846 *
2847  temperature_rhs.reinit(temperature_partitioning,
2848  temperature_relevant_partitioning,
2849  MPI_COMM_WORLD,
2850  true);
2851  temperature_solution.reinit(temperature_relevant_partitioning,
2852  MPI_COMM_WORLD);
2853  old_temperature_solution.reinit(temperature_solution);
2854  old_old_temperature_solution.reinit(temperature_solution);
2855 *
2856  rebuild_stokes_matrix = true;
2857  rebuild_stokes_preconditioner = true;
2858  rebuild_temperature_matrices = true;
2859  rebuild_temperature_preconditioner = true;
2860  }
2861 *
2862 
2863 *
2864  @endcode
2865 *
2866 * <a name="TheBoussinesqFlowProblemassemblyfunctions"></a> <h4>The BoussinesqFlowProblem assembly functions</h4>
