2867 * Following the discussion in the introduction and in the @ref threads module, we split the assembly functions into different parts:
2868 * <ul> <li> The local calculations of matrices and right hand sides, given a certain cell as input (these functions are named <code>local_assemble_*</code> below). The resulting function is, in other words, essentially the body of the loop over all cells in @ref step_31 "step-31" . Note, however, that these functions store the result from the local calculations in variables of classes from the CopyData namespace.
2869 * <li> These objects are then given to the second step which writes the local data into the global data structures (these functions are named <code>copy_local_to_global_*</code> below). These functions are pretty trivial.
2870 * <li> These two subfunctions are then used in the respective assembly routine (called <code>assemble_*</code> below), where a WorkStream object is set up and runs over all the cells that belong to the processor's subdomain. </ul>
2871 *
2872 
2873 *
2874 * <a name="Stokespreconditionerassembly"></a> <h5>Stokes preconditioner assembly</h5>
2875 * Let us start with the functions that builds the Stokes preconditioner. The first two of these are pretty trivial, given the discussion above. Note in particular that the main point in using the scratch data object is that we want to avoid allocating any objects on the free space each time we visit a new cell. As a consequence, the assembly function below only has automatic local variables, and everything else is accessed through the scratch data object, which is allocated only once before we start the loop over all cells:
2876 *
2877 
2878 *
2879 * @code
2880  template <int dim>
2881  void BoussinesqFlowProblem<dim>::local_assemble_stokes_preconditioner(
2882  const typename DoFHandler<dim>::active_cell_iterator &cell,
2883  Assembly::Scratch::StokesPreconditioner<dim> & scratch,
2884  Assembly::CopyData::StokesPreconditioner<dim> & data)
2885  {
2886  const unsigned int dofs_per_cell = stokes_fe.n_dofs_per_cell();
2887  const unsigned int n_q_points =
2888  scratch.stokes_fe_values.n_quadrature_points;
2889 *
2890  const FEValuesExtractors::Vector velocities(0);
2891  const FEValuesExtractors::Scalar pressure(dim);
2892 *
2893  scratch.stokes_fe_values.reinit(cell);
2894  cell->get_dof_indices(data.local_dof_indices);
2895 *
2896  data.local_matrix = 0;
2897 *
2898  for (unsigned int q = 0; q < n_q_points; ++q)
2899  {
2900  for (unsigned int k = 0; k < dofs_per_cell; ++k)
2901  {
2902  scratch.grad_phi_u[k] =
2903  scratch.stokes_fe_values[velocities].gradient(k, q);
2904  scratch.phi_p[k] = scratch.stokes_fe_values[pressure].value(k, q);
2905  }
2906 *
2907  for (unsigned int i = 0; i < dofs_per_cell; ++i)
2908  for (unsigned int j = 0; j < dofs_per_cell; ++j)
2909  data.local_matrix(i, j) +=
2910  (EquationData::eta
2911  scalar_product(scratch.grad_phi_u[i], scratch.grad_phi_u[j]) +
2912  (1. / EquationData::eta) EquationData::pressure_scaling
2913  EquationData::pressure_scaling
2914  (scratch.phi_p[i] scratch.phi_p[j]))
2915  scratch.stokes_fe_values.JxW(q);
2916  }
2917  }
2918 *
2919 
2920 *
2921  template <int dim>
2922  void BoussinesqFlowProblem<dim>::copy_local_to_global_stokes_preconditioner(
2923  const Assembly::CopyData::StokesPreconditioner<dim> &data)
2924  {
2925  stokes_constraints.distribute_local_to_global(data.local_matrix,
2926  data.local_dof_indices,
2927  stokes_preconditioner_matrix);
2928  }
2929 *
2930 
2931  @endcode
2932 *
2933 * Now for the function that actually puts things together, using the WorkStream functions. WorkStream::run needs a start and end iterator to enumerate the cells it is supposed to work on. Typically, one would use DoFHandler::begin_active() and DoFHandler::end() for that but here we actually only want the subset of cells that in fact are owned by the current processor. This is where the FilteredIterator class comes into play: you give it a range of cells and it provides an iterator that only iterates over that subset of cells that satisfy a certain predicate (a predicate is a function of one argument that either returns true or false). The predicate we use here is IteratorFilters::LocallyOwnedCell, i.e., it returns true exactly if the cell is owned by the current processor. The resulting iterator range is then exactly what we need.
2934 * With this obstacle out of the way, we call the WorkStream::run function with this set of cells, scratch and copy objects, and with pointers to two functions: the local assembly and copy-local-to-global function. These functions need to have very specific signatures: three arguments in the first and one argument in the latter case (see the documentation of the WorkStream::run function for the meaning of these arguments). Note how we use a lambda functions to create a function object that satisfies this requirement. It uses function arguments for the local assembly function that specify cell, scratch data, and copy data, as well as function argument for the copy function that expects the data to be written into the global matrix (also see the discussion in @ref step_13 "step-13" 's <code>assemble_linear_system()</code> function). On the other hand, the implicit zeroth argument of member functions (namely the <code>this</code> pointer of the object on which that member function is to operate on) is <i>bound</i> to the <code>this</code> pointer of the current function and is captured. The WorkStream::run function, as a consequence, does not need to know anything about the object these functions work on.
2935 * When the WorkStream is executed, it will create several local assembly routines of the first kind for several cells and let some available processors work on them. The function that needs to be synchronized, i.e., the write operation into the global matrix, however, is executed by only one thread at a time in the prescribed order. Of course, this only holds for the parallelization on a single MPI process. Different MPI processes will have their own WorkStream objects and do that work completely independently (and in different memory spaces). In a distributed calculation, some data will accumulate at degrees of freedom that are not owned by the respective processor. It would be inefficient to send data around every time we encounter such a dof. What happens instead is that the Trilinos sparse matrix will keep that data and send it to the owner at the end of assembly, by calling the <code>compress()</code> command.
2936 *
2937 
2938 *
2939 * @code
2940  template <int dim>
2941  void BoussinesqFlowProblem<dim>::assemble_stokes_preconditioner()
2942  {
2943  stokes_preconditioner_matrix = 0;
2944 *
2945  const QGauss<dim> quadrature_formula(parameters.stokes_velocity_degree + 1);
2946 *
2947  using CellFilter =
2948  FilteredIterator<typename DoFHandler<2>::active_cell_iterator>;
2949 *
2950  auto worker =
2951  [this](const typename DoFHandler<dim>::active_cell_iterator &cell,
2952  Assembly::Scratch::StokesPreconditioner<dim> & scratch,
2953  Assembly::CopyData::StokesPreconditioner<dim> & data) {
2954  this->local_assemble_stokes_preconditioner(cell, scratch, data);
2955  };
2956 *
2957  auto copier =
2958  [this](const Assembly::CopyData::StokesPreconditioner<dim> &data) {
2959  this->copy_local_to_global_stokes_preconditioner(data);
2960  };
2961 *
2962  WorkStream::run(CellFilter(IteratorFilters::LocallyOwnedCell(),
2963  stokes_dof_handler.begin_active()),
2964  CellFilter(IteratorFilters::LocallyOwnedCell(),
2965  stokes_dof_handler.end()),
2966  worker,
2967  copier,
2968  Assembly::Scratch::StokesPreconditioner<dim>(
2969  stokes_fe,
2970  quadrature_formula,
2971  mapping,
2972  update_JxW_values | update_values | update_gradients),
2973  Assembly::CopyData::StokesPreconditioner<dim>(stokes_fe));
2974 *
2975  stokes_preconditioner_matrix.compress(VectorOperation::add);
2976  }
2977 *
2978 
2979 *
2980  @endcode
2981 *
2982 * The final function in this block initiates assembly of the Stokes preconditioner matrix and then in fact builds the Stokes preconditioner. It is mostly the same as in the serial case. The only difference to @ref step_31 "step-31" is that we use a Jacobi preconditioner for the pressure mass matrix instead of IC, as discussed in the introduction.
2983 *
2984 
2985 *
2986 * @code
2987  template <int dim>
2988  void BoussinesqFlowProblem<dim>::build_stokes_preconditioner()
2989  {
2990  if (rebuild_stokes_preconditioner == false)
2991  return;
2992 *
2993  TimerOutput::Scope timer_section(computing_timer,
2994  " Build Stokes preconditioner");
2995  pcout << " Rebuilding Stokes preconditioner..." << std::flush;
2996 *
2997  assemble_stokes_preconditioner();
2998 *
2999  std::vector<std::vector<bool>> constant_modes;
3000  FEValuesExtractors::Vector velocity_components(0);
3001  DoFTools::extract_constant_modes(stokes_dof_handler,
3002  stokes_fe.component_mask(
3003  velocity_components),
3004  constant_modes);
3005 *
3006  Mp_preconditioner =
3007  std::make_shared<TrilinosWrappers::PreconditionJacobi>();
3008  Amg_preconditioner = std::make_shared<TrilinosWrappers::PreconditionAMG>();
3009 *
3010  TrilinosWrappers::PreconditionAMG::AdditionalData Amg_data;
3011  Amg_data.constant_modes = constant_modes;
3012  Amg_data.elliptic = true;
3013  Amg_data.higher_order_elements = true;
3014  Amg_data.smoother_sweeps = 2;
3015  Amg_data.aggregation_threshold = 0.02;
3016 *
3017  Mp_preconditioner->initialize(stokes_preconditioner_matrix.block(1, 1));
3018  Amg_preconditioner->initialize(stokes_preconditioner_matrix.block(0, 0),
3019  Amg_data);
3020 *
3021  rebuild_stokes_preconditioner = false;
3022 *
3023  pcout << std::endl;
3024  }
3025 *
3026 
3027  @endcode
3028 *
3029 * <a name="Stokessystemassembly"></a> <h5>Stokes system assembly</h5>
3030 *
3031 
3032 *
3033 * The next three functions implement the assembly of the Stokes system, again split up into a part performing local calculations, one for writing the local data into the global matrix and vector, and one for actually running the loop over all cells with the help of the WorkStream class. Note that the assembly of the Stokes matrix needs only to be done in case we have changed the mesh. Otherwise, just the (temperature-dependent) right hand side needs to be calculated here. Since we are working with distributed matrices and vectors, we have to call the respective <code>compress()</code> functions in the end of the assembly in order to send non-local data to the owner process.
3034 *
3035 
3036 *
3037 * @code
3038  template <int dim>
3039  void BoussinesqFlowProblem<dim>::local_assemble_stokes_system(
3040  const typename DoFHandler<dim>::active_cell_iterator &cell,
3041  Assembly::Scratch::StokesSystem<dim> & scratch,
3042  Assembly::CopyData::StokesSystem<dim> & data)
3043  {
3044  const unsigned int dofs_per_cell =
3045  scratch.stokes_fe_values.get_fe().n_dofs_per_cell();
3046  const unsigned int n_q_points =
3047  scratch.stokes_fe_values.n_quadrature_points;
3048 *
3049  const FEValuesExtractors::Vector velocities(0);
3050  const FEValuesExtractors::Scalar pressure(dim);
3051 *
3052  scratch.stokes_fe_values.reinit(cell);
3053 *
3054  typename DoFHandler<dim>::active_cell_iterator temperature_cell(
3055  &triangulation, cell->level(), cell->index(), &temperature_dof_handler);
3056  scratch.temperature_fe_values.reinit(temperature_cell);
3057 *
3058  if (rebuild_stokes_matrix)
3059  data.local_matrix = 0;
3060  data.local_rhs = 0;
3061 *
3062  scratch.temperature_fe_values.get_function_values(
3063  old_temperature_solution, scratch.old_temperature_values);
3064 *
3065  for (unsigned int q = 0; q < n_q_points; ++q)
3066  {
3067  const double old_temperature = scratch.old_temperature_values[q];
3068 *
3069  for (unsigned int k = 0; k < dofs_per_cell; ++k)
3070  {
3071  scratch.phi_u[k] = scratch.stokes_fe_values[velocities].value(k, q);
3072  if (rebuild_stokes_matrix)
3073  {
3074  scratch.grads_phi_u[k] =
3075  scratch.stokes_fe_values[velocities].symmetric_gradient(k, q);
3076  scratch.div_phi_u[k] =
3077  scratch.stokes_fe_values[velocities].divergence(k, q);
3078  scratch.phi_p[k] =
3079  scratch.stokes_fe_values[pressure].value(k, q);
3080  }
3081  }
3082 *
3083  if (rebuild_stokes_matrix == true)
3084  for (unsigned int i = 0; i < dofs_per_cell; ++i)
3085  for (unsigned int j = 0; j < dofs_per_cell; ++j)
3086  data.local_matrix(i, j) +=
3087  (EquationData::eta 2
3088  (scratch.grads_phi_u[i] scratch.grads_phi_u[j])
3089 *
3090 -
3091  (EquationData::pressure_scaling scratch.div_phi_u[i]
3092  scratch.phi_p[j])
3093 *
3094 -
3095  (EquationData::pressure_scaling scratch.phi_p[i]
3096  scratch.div_phi_u[j]))
3097  scratch.stokes_fe_values.JxW(q);
3098 *
3099  const Tensor<1, dim> gravity = EquationData::gravity_vector(
3100  scratch.stokes_fe_values.quadrature_point(q));
3101 *
3102  for (unsigned int i = 0; i < dofs_per_cell; ++i)
3103  data.local_rhs(i) += (EquationData::density(old_temperature)
3104  gravity scratch.phi_u[i])
3105  scratch.stokes_fe_values.JxW(q);
3106  }
3107 *
3108  cell->get_dof_indices(data.local_dof_indices);
3109  }
3110 *
3111 
3112 *
3113  template <int dim>
3114  void BoussinesqFlowProblem<dim>::copy_local_to_global_stokes_system(
3115  const Assembly::CopyData::StokesSystem<dim> &data)
3116  {
3117  if (rebuild_stokes_matrix == true)
3118  stokes_constraints.distribute_local_to_global(data.local_matrix,
3119  data.local_rhs,
3120  data.local_dof_indices,
3121  stokes_matrix,
3122  stokes_rhs);
3123  else
3124  stokes_constraints.distribute_local_to_global(data.local_rhs,
3125  data.local_dof_indices,
3126  stokes_rhs);
3127  }
3128 *
3129 
3130 *
3131  template <int dim>
3132  void BoussinesqFlowProblem<dim>::assemble_stokes_system()
3133  {
3134  TimerOutput::Scope timer_section(computing_timer,
3135  " Assemble Stokes system");
3136 *
3137  if (rebuild_stokes_matrix == true)
3138  stokes_matrix = 0;
3139 *
3140  stokes_rhs = 0;
3141 *
3142  const QGauss<dim> quadrature_formula(parameters.stokes_velocity_degree + 1);
3143 *
3144  using CellFilter =
3145  FilteredIterator<typename DoFHandler<2>::active_cell_iterator>;
3146 *
3147  WorkStream::run(
3148  CellFilter(IteratorFilters::LocallyOwnedCell(),
3149  stokes_dof_handler.begin_active()),
3150  CellFilter(IteratorFilters::LocallyOwnedCell(), stokes_dof_handler.end()),
3151  [this](const typename DoFHandler<dim>::active_cell_iterator &cell,
3152  Assembly::Scratch::StokesSystem<dim> & scratch,
3153  Assembly::CopyData::StokesSystem<dim> & data) {
3154  this->local_assemble_stokes_system(cell, scratch, data);
3155  },
3156  [this](const Assembly::CopyData::StokesSystem<dim> &data) {
3157  this->copy_local_to_global_stokes_system(data);
3158  },
3159  Assembly::Scratch::StokesSystem<dim>(
3160  stokes_fe,
3161  mapping,
3162  quadrature_formula,
3163  (update_values | update_quadrature_points | update_JxW_values |
3164  (rebuild_stokes_matrix == true ? update_gradients : UpdateFlags(0))),
3165  temperature_fe,
3166  update_values),
3167  Assembly::CopyData::StokesSystem<dim>(stokes_fe));
3168 *
3169  if (rebuild_stokes_matrix == true)
3170  stokes_matrix.compress(VectorOperation::add);
3171  stokes_rhs.compress(VectorOperation::add);
3172 *
3173  rebuild_stokes_matrix = false;
3174 *
3175  pcout << std::endl;
3176  }
3177 *
3178 
3179  @endcode
3180 *
3181 * <a name="Temperaturematrixassembly"></a> <h5>Temperature matrix assembly</h5>
3182 *
3183 
3184 *
3185 * The task to be performed by the next three functions is to calculate a mass matrix and a Laplace matrix on the temperature system. These will be combined in order to yield the semi-implicit time stepping matrix that consists of the mass matrix plus a time step- dependent weight factor times the Laplace matrix. This function is again essentially the body of the loop over all cells from @ref step_31 "step-31" .
3186 * The two following functions perform similar services as the ones above.
3187 *
3188 
3189 *
3190 * @code
3191  template <int dim>
3192  void BoussinesqFlowProblem<dim>::local_assemble_temperature_matrix(
3193  const typename DoFHandler<dim>::active_cell_iterator &cell,
3194  Assembly::Scratch::TemperatureMatrix<dim> & scratch,
3195  Assembly::CopyData::TemperatureMatrix<dim> & data)
3196  {
3197  const unsigned int dofs_per_cell =
3198  scratch.temperature_fe_values.get_fe().n_dofs_per_cell();
3199  const unsigned int n_q_points =
3200  scratch.temperature_fe_values.n_quadrature_points;
3201 *
3202  scratch.temperature_fe_values.reinit(cell);
3203  cell->get_dof_indices(data.local_dof_indices);
3204 *
3205  data.local_mass_matrix = 0;
3206  data.local_stiffness_matrix = 0;
3207 *
3208  for (unsigned int q = 0; q < n_q_points; ++q)
3209  {
3210  for (unsigned int k = 0; k < dofs_per_cell; ++k)
3211  {
3212  scratch.grad_phi_T[k] =
3213  scratch.temperature_fe_values.shape_grad(k, q);
3214  scratch.phi_T[k] = scratch.temperature_fe_values.shape_value(k, q);
3215  }
3216 *
3217  for (unsigned int i = 0; i < dofs_per_cell; ++i)
3218  for (unsigned int j = 0; j < dofs_per_cell; ++j)
3219  {
3220  data.local_mass_matrix(i, j) +=
3221  (scratch.phi_T[i] scratch.phi_T[j]
3222  scratch.temperature_fe_values.JxW(q));
3223  data.local_stiffness_matrix(i, j) +=
3224  (EquationData::kappa scratch.grad_phi_T[i]
3225  scratch.grad_phi_T[j] scratch.temperature_fe_values.JxW(q));
3226  }
3227  }
3228  }
3229 *
3230 
3231 *
3232  template <int dim>
3233  void BoussinesqFlowProblem<dim>::copy_local_to_global_temperature_matrix(
3234  const Assembly::CopyData::TemperatureMatrix<dim> &data)
3235  {
3236  temperature_constraints.distribute_local_to_global(data.local_mass_matrix,
3237  data.local_dof_indices,
3238  temperature_mass_matrix);
3239  temperature_constraints.distribute_local_to_global(
3240  data.local_stiffness_matrix,
3241  data.local_dof_indices,
3242  temperature_stiffness_matrix);
3243  }
3244 *
3245 
3246  template <int dim>
3247  void BoussinesqFlowProblem<dim>::assemble_temperature_matrix()
3248  {
3249  if (rebuild_temperature_matrices == false)
3250  return;
3251 *
3252  TimerOutput::Scope timer_section(computing_timer,
3253  " Assemble temperature matrices");
3254  temperature_mass_matrix = 0;
3255  temperature_stiffness_matrix = 0;
3256 *
3257  const QGauss<dim> quadrature_formula(parameters.temperature_degree + 2);
3258 *
3259  using CellFilter =
3260  FilteredIterator<typename DoFHandler<2>::active_cell_iterator>;
3261 *
3262  WorkStream::run(
3263  CellFilter(IteratorFilters::LocallyOwnedCell(),
3264  temperature_dof_handler.begin_active()),
3265  CellFilter(IteratorFilters::LocallyOwnedCell(),
3266  temperature_dof_handler.end()),
3267  [this](const typename DoFHandler<dim>::active_cell_iterator &cell,
3268  Assembly::Scratch::TemperatureMatrix<dim> & scratch,
3269  Assembly::CopyData::TemperatureMatrix<dim> & data) {
3270  this->local_assemble_temperature_matrix(cell, scratch, data);
3271  },
3272  [this](const Assembly::CopyData::TemperatureMatrix<dim> &data) {
3273  this->copy_local_to_global_temperature_matrix(data);
3274  },
3275  Assembly::Scratch::TemperatureMatrix<dim>(temperature_fe,
3276  mapping,
3277  quadrature_formula),
3278  Assembly::CopyData::TemperatureMatrix<dim>(temperature_fe));
3279 *
3280  temperature_mass_matrix.compress(VectorOperation::add);
3281  temperature_stiffness_matrix.compress(VectorOperation::add);
3282 *
3283  rebuild_temperature_matrices = false;
3284  rebuild_temperature_preconditioner = true;
3285  }
3286 *
3287 
3288  @endcode
3289 *
3290 * <a name="Temperaturerighthandsideassembly"></a> <h5>Temperature right hand side assembly</h5>
3291 *
3292 
3293 *
3294 * This is the last assembly function. It calculates the right hand side of the temperature system, which includes the convection and the stabilization terms. It includes a lot of evaluations of old solutions at the quadrature points (which are necessary for calculating the artificial viscosity of stabilization), but is otherwise similar to the other assembly functions. Notice, once again, how we resolve the dilemma of having inhomogeneous boundary conditions, by just making a right hand side at this point (compare the comments for the <code>project()</code> function above): We create some matrix columns with exactly the values that would be entered for the temperature stiffness matrix, in case we have inhomogeneously constrained dofs. That will account for the correct balance of the right hand side vector with the matrix system of temperature.
3295 *
3296 
3297 *
3298 * @code
3299  template <int dim>
3300  void BoussinesqFlowProblem<dim>::local_assemble_temperature_rhs(
3301  const std::pair<double, double> global_T_range,
3302  const double global_max_velocity,
3303  const double global_entropy_variation,
3304  const typename DoFHandler<dim>::active_cell_iterator &cell,
3305  Assembly::Scratch::TemperatureRHS<dim> & scratch,
3306  Assembly::CopyData::TemperatureRHS<dim> & data)
3307  {
3308  const bool use_bdf2_scheme = (timestep_number != 0);
3309 *
3310  const unsigned int dofs_per_cell =
3311  scratch.temperature_fe_values.get_fe().n_dofs_per_cell();
3312  const unsigned int n_q_points =
3313  scratch.temperature_fe_values.n_quadrature_points;
3314 *
3315  const FEValuesExtractors::Vector velocities(0);
3316 *
3317  data.local_rhs = 0;
3318  data.matrix_for_bc = 0;
3319  cell->get_dof_indices(data.local_dof_indices);
3320 *
3321  scratch.temperature_fe_values.reinit(cell);
3322 *
3323  typename DoFHandler<dim>::active_cell_iterator stokes_cell(
3324  &triangulation, cell->level(), cell->index(), &stokes_dof_handler);
3325  scratch.stokes_fe_values.reinit(stokes_cell);
3326 *
3327  scratch.temperature_fe_values.get_function_values(
3328  old_temperature_solution, scratch.old_temperature_values);
3329  scratch.temperature_fe_values.get_function_values(
3330  old_old_temperature_solution, scratch.old_old_temperature_values);
3331 *
3332  scratch.temperature_fe_values.get_function_gradients(
3333  old_temperature_solution, scratch.old_temperature_grads);
3334  scratch.temperature_fe_values.get_function_gradients(
3335  old_old_temperature_solution, scratch.old_old_temperature_grads);
3336 *
3337  scratch.temperature_fe_values.get_function_laplacians(
3338  old_temperature_solution, scratch.old_temperature_laplacians);
3339  scratch.temperature_fe_values.get_function_laplacians(
3340  old_old_temperature_solution, scratch.old_old_temperature_laplacians);
3341 *
3342  scratch.stokes_fe_values[velocities].get_function_values(
3343  stokes_solution, scratch.old_velocity_values);
3344  scratch.stokes_fe_values[velocities].get_function_values(
3345  old_stokes_solution, scratch.old_old_velocity_values);
3346  scratch.stokes_fe_values[velocities].get_function_symmetric_gradients(
3347  stokes_solution, scratch.old_strain_rates);
3348  scratch.stokes_fe_values[velocities].get_function_symmetric_gradients(
3349  old_stokes_solution, scratch.old_old_strain_rates);
3350 *
3351  const double nu =
3352  compute_viscosity(scratch.old_temperature_values,
3353  scratch.old_old_temperature_values,
3354  scratch.old_temperature_grads,
3355  scratch.old_old_temperature_grads,
3356  scratch.old_temperature_laplacians,
3357  scratch.old_old_temperature_laplacians,
3358  scratch.old_velocity_values,
3359  scratch.old_old_velocity_values,
3360  scratch.old_strain_rates,
3361  scratch.old_old_strain_rates,
3362  global_max_velocity,
3363  global_T_range.second
3364 *
3365 - global_T_range.first,
3366  0.5 (global_T_range.second + global_T_range.first),
3367  global_entropy_variation,
3368  cell->diameter());
3369 *
3370  for (unsigned int q = 0; q < n_q_points; ++q)
3371  {
3372  for (unsigned int k = 0; k < dofs_per_cell; ++k)
3373  {
3374  scratch.phi_T[k] = scratch.temperature_fe_values.shape_value(k, q);
3375  scratch.grad_phi_T[k] =
3376  scratch.temperature_fe_values.shape_grad(k, q);
3377  }
3378 *
3379 
3380  const double T_term_for_rhs =
3381  (use_bdf2_scheme ?
3382  (scratch.old_temperature_values[q]
3383  (1 + time_step / old_time_step)
3384 *
3385 -
3386  scratch.old_old_temperature_values[q] (time_step time_step) /
3387  (old_time_step (time_step + old_time_step))) :
3388  scratch.old_temperature_values[q]);
3389 *
3390  const double ext_T =
3391  (use_bdf2_scheme ? (scratch.old_temperature_values[q]
3392  (1 + time_step / old_time_step)
3393 *
3394 -
3395  scratch.old_old_temperature_values[q]
3396  time_step / old_time_step) :
3397  scratch.old_temperature_values[q]);
3398 *
3399  const Tensor<1, dim> ext_grad_T =
3400  (use_bdf2_scheme ? (scratch.old_temperature_grads[q]
3401  (1 + time_step / old_time_step)
3402 *
3403 -
3404  scratch.old_old_temperature_grads[q] time_step /
3405  old_time_step) :
3406  scratch.old_temperature_grads[q]);
3407 *
3408  const Tensor<1, dim> extrapolated_u =
3409  (use_bdf2_scheme ?
3410  (scratch.old_velocity_values[q] (1 + time_step / old_time_step)
3411 *
3412 -
3413  scratch.old_old_velocity_values[q] time_step / old_time_step) :
3414  scratch.old_velocity_values[q]);
3415 *
3416  const SymmetricTensor<2, dim> extrapolated_strain_rate =
3417  (use_bdf2_scheme ?
3418  (scratch.old_strain_rates[q] (1 + time_step / old_time_step)
3419 *
3420 -
3421  scratch.old_old_strain_rates[q] time_step / old_time_step) :
3422  scratch.old_strain_rates[q]);
3423 *
3424  const double gamma =
3425  ((EquationData::radiogenic_heating EquationData::density(ext_T) +
3426  2 EquationData::eta extrapolated_strain_rate
3427  extrapolated_strain_rate) /
3428  (EquationData::density(ext_T) EquationData::specific_heat));
3429 *
3430  for (unsigned int i = 0; i < dofs_per_cell; ++i)
3431  {
3432  data.local_rhs(i) +=
3433  (T_term_for_rhs scratch.phi_T[i]
3434 *
3435 -
3436  time_step extrapolated_u ext_grad_T scratch.phi_T[i]
3437 *
3438 -
3439  time_step nu ext_grad_T scratch.grad_phi_T[i] +
3440  time_step gamma scratch.phi_T[i])
3441  scratch.temperature_fe_values.JxW(q);
3442 *
3443  if (temperature_constraints.is_inhomogeneously_constrained(
3444  data.local_dof_indices[i]))
3445  {
3446  for (unsigned int j = 0; j < dofs_per_cell; ++j)
3447  data.matrix_for_bc(j, i) +=
3448  (scratch.phi_T[i] scratch.phi_T[j]
3449  (use_bdf2_scheme ? ((2 time_step + old_time_step) /
3450  (time_step + old_time_step)) :
3451  1.) +
3452  scratch.grad_phi_T[i] scratch.grad_phi_T[j]
3453  EquationData::kappa time_step)
3454  scratch.temperature_fe_values.JxW(q);
3455  }
3456  }
3457  }
3458  }
3459 *
3460 
3461  template <int dim>
3462  void BoussinesqFlowProblem<dim>::copy_local_to_global_temperature_rhs(
3463  const Assembly::CopyData::TemperatureRHS<dim> &data)
3464  {
3465  temperature_constraints.distribute_local_to_global(data.local_rhs,
3466  data.local_dof_indices,
3467  temperature_rhs,
3468  data.matrix_for_bc);
3469  }
3470 *
3471 
3472 *
3473  @endcode
3474 *
3475 * In the function that runs the WorkStream for actually calculating the right hand side, we also generate the final matrix. As mentioned above, it is a sum of the mass matrix and the Laplace matrix, times some time step- dependent weight. This weight is specified by the BDF-2 time integration scheme, see the introduction in @ref step_31 "step-31" . What is new in this tutorial program (in addition to the use of MPI parallelization and the WorkStream class), is that we now precompute the temperature preconditioner as well. The reason is that the setup of the Jacobi preconditioner takes a noticeable time compared to the solver because we usually only need between 10 and 20 iterations for solving the temperature system (this might sound strange, as Jacobi really only consists of a diagonal, but in Trilinos it is derived from more general framework for point relaxation preconditioners which is a bit inefficient). Hence, it is more efficient to precompute the preconditioner, even though the matrix entries may slightly change because the time step might change. This is not too big a problem because we remesh every few time steps (and regenerate the preconditioner then).
3476 *
3477 
3478 *
3479 * @code
3480  template <int dim>
3481  void BoussinesqFlowProblem<dim>::assemble_temperature_system(
3482  const double maximal_velocity)
3483  {
3484  const bool use_bdf2_scheme = (timestep_number != 0);
3485 *
3486  if (use_bdf2_scheme == true)
3487  {
3488  temperature_matrix.copy_from(temperature_mass_matrix);
3489  temperature_matrix=
3490  (2 time_step + old_time_step) / (time_step + old_time_step);
3491  temperature_matrix.add(time_step, temperature_stiffness_matrix);
3492  }
3493  else
3494  {
3495  temperature_matrix.copy_from(temperature_mass_matrix);
3496  temperature_matrix.add(time_step, temperature_stiffness_matrix);
3497  }
3498 *
3499  if (rebuild_temperature_preconditioner == true)
3500  {
3501  T_preconditioner =
3502  std::make_shared<TrilinosWrappers::PreconditionJacobi>();
3503  T_preconditioner->initialize(temperature_matrix);
3504  rebuild_temperature_preconditioner = false;
3505  }
3506 *
3507  @endcode
3508 *
3509 * The next part is computing the right hand side vectors. To do so, we first compute the average temperature @f$T_m@f$ that we use for evaluating the artificial viscosity stabilization through the residual @f$E(T) =
3510  (T-T_m)^2@f$ . We do this by defining the midpoint between maximum and minimum temperature as average temperature in the definition of the entropy viscosity. An alternative would be to use the integral average, but the results are not very sensitive to this choice. The rest then only requires calling WorkStream::run again, binding the arguments to the <code>local_assemble_temperature_rhs</code> function that are the same in every call to the correct values:
3511 *
3512 
3513 *
3514 * @code
3515  temperature_rhs = 0;
3516 *
3517  const QGauss<dim> quadrature_formula(parameters.temperature_degree + 2);
3518  const std::pair<double, double> global_T_range =
3519  get_extrapolated_temperature_range();
3520 *
3521  const double average_temperature =
3522  0.5 (global_T_range.first + global_T_range.second);
3523  const double global_entropy_variation =
3524  get_entropy_variation(average_temperature);
3525 *
3526  using CellFilter =
3527  FilteredIterator<typename DoFHandler<2>::active_cell_iterator>;
3528 *
3529  auto worker =
3530  [this, global_T_range, maximal_velocity, global_entropy_variation](
3531  const typename DoFHandler<dim>::active_cell_iterator &cell,
3532  Assembly::Scratch::TemperatureRHS<dim> & scratch,
3533  Assembly::CopyData::TemperatureRHS<dim> & data) {
3534  this->local_assemble_temperature_rhs(global_T_range,
3535  maximal_velocity,
3536  global_entropy_variation,
3537  cell,
3538  scratch,
3539  data);
3540  };
3541 *
3542  auto copier = [this](const Assembly::CopyData::TemperatureRHS<dim> &data) {
3543  this->copy_local_to_global_temperature_rhs(data);
3544  };
3545 *
3546  WorkStream::run(CellFilter(IteratorFilters::LocallyOwnedCell(),
3547  temperature_dof_handler.begin_active()),
3548  CellFilter(IteratorFilters::LocallyOwnedCell(),
3549  temperature_dof_handler.end()),
3550  worker,
3551  copier,
3552  Assembly::Scratch::TemperatureRHS<dim>(
3553  temperature_fe, stokes_fe, mapping, quadrature_formula),
3554  Assembly::CopyData::TemperatureRHS<dim>(temperature_fe));
3555 *
3556  temperature_rhs.compress(VectorOperation::add);
3557  }
3558 *
3559 
3560 *
3561  @endcode
3562 *
3563 * <a name="BoussinesqFlowProblemsolve"></a> <h4>BoussinesqFlowProblem::solve</h4>
3564 *
3565 
3566 *
3567 * This function solves the linear systems in each time step of the Boussinesq problem. First, we work on the Stokes system and then on the temperature system. In essence, it does the same things as the respective function in @ref step_31 "step-31" . However, there are a few changes here.
3568 * The first change is related to the way we store our solution: we keep the vectors with locally owned degrees of freedom plus ghost nodes on each MPI node. When we enter a solver which is supposed to perform matrix-vector products with a distributed matrix, this is not the appropriate form, though. There, we will want to have the solution vector to be distributed in the same way as the matrix, i.e. without any ghosts. So what we do first is to generate a distributed vector called <code>distributed_stokes_solution</code> and put only the locally owned dofs into that, which is neatly done by the <code>operator=</code> of the Trilinos vector.
3569 * Next, we scale the pressure solution (or rather, the initial guess) for the solver so that it matches with the length scales in the matrices, as discussed in the introduction. We also immediately scale the pressure solution back to the correct units after the solution is completed. We also need to set the pressure values at hanging nodes to zero. This we also did in @ref step_31 "step-31" in order not to disturb the Schur complement by some vector entries that actually are irrelevant during the solve stage. As a difference to @ref step_31 "step-31" , here we do it only for the locally owned pressure dofs. After solving for the Stokes solution, each processor copies the distributed solution back into the solution vector that also includes ghost elements.
3570 * The third and most obvious change is that we have two variants for the Stokes solver: A fast solver that sometimes breaks down, and a robust solver that is slower. This is what we already discussed in the introduction. Here is how we realize it: First, we perform 30 iterations with the fast solver based on the simple preconditioner based on the AMG V-cycle instead of an approximate solve (this is indicated by the <code>false</code> argument to the <code>LinearSolvers::BlockSchurPreconditioner</code> object). If we converge, everything is fine. If we do not converge, the solver control object will throw an exception SolverControl::NoConvergence. Usually, this would abort the program because we don't catch them in our usual <code>solve()</code> functions. This is certainly not what we want to happen here. Rather, we want to switch to the strong solver and continue the solution process with whatever vector we got so far. Hence, we catch the exception with the C++ try/catch mechanism. We then simply go through the same solver sequence again in the <code>catch</code> clause, this time passing the @p true flag to the preconditioner for the strong solver, signaling an approximate CG solve.
3571 *
3572 
3573 *
3574 * @code
3575  template <int dim>
3576  void BoussinesqFlowProblem<dim>::solve()
3577  {
3578  {
3579  TimerOutput::Scope timer_section(computing_timer,
3580  " Solve Stokes system");
3581 *
3582  pcout << " Solving Stokes system... " << std::flush;
3583 *
3584  TrilinosWrappers::MPI::BlockVector distributed_stokes_solution(
3585  stokes_rhs);
3586  distributed_stokes_solution = stokes_solution;
3587 *
3588  distributed_stokes_solution.block(1) /= EquationData::pressure_scaling;
3589 *
3590  const unsigned int
3591  start = (distributed_stokes_solution.block(0).size() +
3592  distributed_stokes_solution.block(1).local_range().first),
3593  end = (distributed_stokes_solution.block(0).size() +
3594  distributed_stokes_solution.block(1).local_range().second);
3595  for (unsigned int i = start; i < end; ++i)
3596  if (stokes_constraints.is_constrained(i))
3597  distributed_stokes_solution(i) = 0;
3598 *
3599 
3600  PrimitiveVectorMemory<TrilinosWrappers::MPI::BlockVector> mem;
3601 *
3602  unsigned int n_iterations = 0;
3603  const double solver_tolerance = 1e-8 stokes_rhs.l2_norm();
3604  SolverControl solver_control(30, solver_tolerance);
3605 *
3606  try
3607  {
3608  const LinearSolvers::BlockSchurPreconditioner<
3609  TrilinosWrappers::PreconditionAMG,
3610  TrilinosWrappers::PreconditionJacobi>
3611  preconditioner(stokes_matrix,
3612  stokes_preconditioner_matrix,
3613  Mp_preconditioner,
3614  Amg_preconditioner,
3615  false);
3616 *
3617  SolverFGMRES<TrilinosWrappers::MPI::BlockVector> solver(
3618  solver_control,
3619  mem,
3620  SolverFGMRES<TrilinosWrappers::MPI::BlockVector>::AdditionalData(
3621  30));
3622  solver.solve(stokes_matrix,
3623  distributed_stokes_solution,
3624  stokes_rhs,
3625  preconditioner);
3626 *
3627  n_iterations = solver_control.last_step();
3628  }
3629 *
3630  catch (SolverControl::NoConvergence &)
3631  {
3632  const LinearSolvers::BlockSchurPreconditioner<
3633  TrilinosWrappers::PreconditionAMG,
3634  TrilinosWrappers::PreconditionJacobi>
3635  preconditioner(stokes_matrix,
3636  stokes_preconditioner_matrix,
3637  Mp_preconditioner,
3638  Amg_preconditioner,
3639  true);
3640 *
3641  SolverControl solver_control_refined(stokes_matrix.m(),
3642  solver_tolerance);
3643  SolverFGMRES<TrilinosWrappers::MPI::BlockVector> solver(
3644  solver_control_refined,
3645  mem,
3646  SolverFGMRES<TrilinosWrappers::MPI::BlockVector>::AdditionalData(
3647  50));
3648  solver.solve(stokes_matrix,
3649  distributed_stokes_solution,
3650  stokes_rhs,
3651  preconditioner);
3652 *
3653  n_iterations =
3654  (solver_control.last_step() + solver_control_refined.last_step());
3655  }
3656 *
3657 
3658  stokes_constraints.distribute(distributed_stokes_solution);
3659 *
3660  distributed_stokes_solution.block(1)= EquationData::pressure_scaling;
3661 *
3662  stokes_solution = distributed_stokes_solution;
3663  pcout << n_iterations << " iterations." << std::endl;
3664  }
3665 *
3666 
3667  @endcode
3668 *
3669 * Now let's turn to the temperature part: First, we compute the time step size. We found that we need smaller time steps for 3D than for 2D for the shell geometry. This is because the cells are more distorted in that case (it is the smallest edge length that determines the CFL number). Instead of computing the time step from maximum velocity and minimal mesh size as in @ref step_31 "step-31" , we compute local CFL numbers, i.e., on each cell we compute the maximum velocity times the mesh size, and compute the maximum of them. Hence, we need to choose the factor in front of the time step slightly smaller.
3670 * After temperature right hand side assembly, we solve the linear system for temperature (with fully distributed vectors without any ghosts), apply constraints and copy the vector back to one with ghosts.
3671 * In the end, we extract the temperature range similarly to @ref step_31 "step-31" to produce some output (for example in order to help us choose the stabilization constants, as discussed in the introduction). The only difference is that we need to exchange maxima over all processors.
3672 *
3673 
3674 *
3675 * @code
3676  {
3677  TimerOutput::Scope timer_section(computing_timer,
3678  " Assemble temperature rhs");
3679 *
3680  old_time_step = time_step;
3681 *
3682  const double scaling = (dim == 3 ? 0.25 : 1.0);
3683  time_step = (scaling / (2.1 dim std::sqrt(1. dim)) /
3684  (parameters.temperature_degree get_cfl_number()));
3685 *
3686  const double maximal_velocity = get_maximal_velocity();
3687  pcout << " Maximal velocity: "
3688  << maximal_velocity EquationData::year_in_seconds 100
3689  << " cm/year" << std::endl;
3690  pcout << " "
3691  << "Time step: " << time_step / EquationData::year_in_seconds
3692  << " years" << std::endl;
3693 *
3694  temperature_solution = old_temperature_solution;
3695  assemble_temperature_system(maximal_velocity);
3696  }
3697 *
3698  {
3699  TimerOutput::Scope timer_section(computing_timer,
3700  " Solve temperature system");
3701 *
3702  SolverControl solver_control(temperature_matrix.m(),
3703  1e-12 temperature_rhs.l2_norm());
3704  SolverCG<TrilinosWrappers::MPI::Vector> cg(solver_control);
3705 *
3706  TrilinosWrappers::MPI::Vector distributed_temperature_solution(
3707  temperature_rhs);
3708  distributed_temperature_solution = temperature_solution;
3709 *
3710  cg.solve(temperature_matrix,
3711  distributed_temperature_solution,
3712  temperature_rhs,
3713  T_preconditioner);
3714 *
3715  temperature_constraints.distribute(distributed_temperature_solution);
3716  temperature_solution = distributed_temperature_solution;
3717 *
3718  pcout << " " << solver_control.last_step()
3719  << " CG iterations for temperature" << std::endl;
3720 *
3721  double temperature[2] = {std::numeric_limits<double>::max(),
3722 *
3723 
3724 
3725 *
3726 *
3727 
3728 
3729 *
3730 *
3731 
3732 
3733 *
3734 *
3735 
3736 
3737 *
3738 *
3739 
3740 
3741 *
3742 *
3743 
3744 
3745 *
3746 *
3747 
3748 
3749 *
3750 *
3751 
3752 
3753 *
3754 *
3755 
3756 
3757 *
3758 *
3759 
3760 
3761 *
3762 *
3763 
3764 
3765 *
3766 *
3767 
3768 
3769 *
3770 *
3771 
3772 
3773 *
3774 *
3775 
3776 
3777 *
3778 *
3779 
3780 
3781 *
3782 *
3783 
3784 
3785 *
3786 *
3787 
3788 
3789 *
3790 *
3791 
3792 
3793 *
3794 *
3795 
3796 
3797 *
3798 *
3799 
3800 
3801 *
3802 *
3803 
3804 
3805 *
3806 *
3807 
3808 
3809 *
3810 *
3811 
3812 
3813 *
3814 *
3815 
3816 
3817 *
3818 *
3819 
3820 
3821 *
3822 *
3823 
3824 
3825 *
3826 *
3827 
3828 
3829 *
3830 *
3831 
3832 
3833 *
3834 *
3835 
3836 
3837 *
3838 *
3839 
3840 
3841 *
3842 *
3843 
3844 
3845 *
3846 *
3847 
3848 
3849 *
3850 *
3851 -std::numeric_limits<double>::max()};
3852  double global_temperature[2];
3853 *
3854  for (unsigned int i =
3855  distributed_temperature_solution.local_range().first;
3856  i < distributed_temperature_solution.local_range().second;
3857  ++i)
3858  {
3859  temperature[0] =
3860  std::min<double>(temperature[0],
3861  distributed_temperature_solution(i));
3862  temperature[1] =
3863  std::max<double>(temperature[1],
3864  distributed_temperature_solution(i));
3865  }
3866 *
3867  temperature[0]=
3868 *
3869 -1.0;
3870  Utilities::MPI::max(temperature, MPI_COMM_WORLD, global_temperature);
3871  global_temperature[0]=
3872 *
3873 -1.0;
3874 *
3875  pcout << " Temperature range: " << global_temperature[0] << ' '
3876  << global_temperature[1] << std::endl;
3877  }
3878  }
3879 *
3880 
3881  @endcode
3882 *
3883 * <a name="BoussinesqFlowProblemoutput_results"></a> <h4>BoussinesqFlowProblem::output_results</h4>
3884 *
3885 
3886 *
3887 * Next comes the function that generates the output. The quantities to output could be introduced manually like we did in @ref step_31 "step-31" . An alternative is to hand this task over to a class PostProcessor that inherits from the class DataPostprocessor, which can be attached to DataOut. This allows us to output derived quantities from the solution, like the friction heating included in this example. It overloads the virtual function DataPostprocessor::evaluate_vector_field(), which is then internally called from DataOut::build_patches(). We have to give it values of the numerical solution, its derivatives, normals to the cell, the actual evaluation points and any additional quantities. This follows the same procedure as discussed in @ref step_29 "step-29" and other programs.
3888 *
3889 
3890 *
3891 * @code
3892  template <int dim>
3893  class BoussinesqFlowProblem<dim>::Postprocessor
3894  : public DataPostprocessor<dim>
3895  {
3896  public:
3897  Postprocessor(const unsigned int partition, const double minimal_pressure);
3898 *
3899  virtual void evaluate_vector_field(
3900  const DataPostprocessorInputs::Vector<dim> &inputs,
3901  std::vector<Vector<double>> &computed_quantities) const override;
3902 *
3903  virtual std::vector<std::string> get_names() const override;
3904 *
3905  virtual std::vector<
3906  DataComponentInterpretation::DataComponentInterpretation>
3907  get_data_component_interpretation() const override;
3908 *
3909  virtual UpdateFlags get_needed_update_flags() const override;
3910 *
3911  private:
3912  const unsigned int partition;
3913  const double minimal_pressure;
3914  };
3915 *
3916 
3917  template <int dim>
3918  BoussinesqFlowProblem<dim>::Postprocessor::Postprocessor(
3919  const unsigned int partition,
3920  const double minimal_pressure)
3921  : partition(partition)
3922  , minimal_pressure(minimal_pressure)
3923  {}
3924 *
3925 
3926  @endcode
3927 *
3928 * Here we define the names for the variables we want to output. These are the actual solution values for velocity, pressure, and temperature, as well as the friction heating and to each cell the number of the processor that owns it. This allows us to visualize the partitioning of the domain among the processors. Except for the velocity, which is vector-valued, all other quantities are scalar.
3929 *
3930 
3931 *
3932 * @code
3933  template <int dim>
3934  std::vector<std::string>
3935  BoussinesqFlowProblem<dim>::Postprocessor::get_names() const
3936  {
3937  std::vector<std::string> solution_names(dim, "velocity");
3938  solution_names.emplace_back("p");
3939  solution_names.emplace_back("T");
3940  solution_names.emplace_back("friction_heating");
3941  solution_names.emplace_back("partition");
3942 *
3943  return solution_names;
3944  }
3945 *
3946 
3947  template <int dim>
3948  std::vector<DataComponentInterpretation::DataComponentInterpretation>
3949  BoussinesqFlowProblem<dim>::Postprocessor::get_data_component_interpretation()
3950  const
3951  {
3952  std::vector<DataComponentInterpretation::DataComponentInterpretation>
3953  interpretation(dim,
3954  DataComponentInterpretation::component_is_part_of_vector);
3955 *
3956  interpretation.push_back(DataComponentInterpretation::component_is_scalar);
3957  interpretation.push_back(DataComponentInterpretation::component_is_scalar);
3958  interpretation.push_back(DataComponentInterpretation::component_is_scalar);
3959  interpretation.push_back(DataComponentInterpretation::component_is_scalar);
3960 *
3961  return interpretation;
3962  }
3963 *
3964 
3965  template <int dim>
3966  UpdateFlags
3967  BoussinesqFlowProblem<dim>::Postprocessor::get_needed_update_flags() const
3968  {
3969  return update_values | update_gradients | update_quadrature_points;
3970  }
3971 *
3972 
3973  @endcode
3974 *
3975 * Now we implement the function that computes the derived quantities. As we also did for the output, we rescale the velocity from its SI units to something more readable, namely cm/year. Next, the pressure is scaled to be between 0 and the maximum pressure. This makes it more easily comparable
3976 *
3977 * - in essence making all pressure variables positive or zero. Temperature is taken as is, and the friction heating is computed as @f$2 \eta \varepsilon(\mathbf{u}) \cdot \varepsilon(\mathbf{u})@f$ .
3978 * The quantities we output here are more for illustration, rather than for actual scientific value. We come back to this briefly in the results section of this program and explain what one may in fact be interested in.
3979 *
3980 
3981 *
3982 * @code
3983  template <int dim>
3984  void BoussinesqFlowProblem<dim>::Postprocessor::evaluate_vector_field(
3985  const DataPostprocessorInputs::Vector<dim> &inputs,
3986  std::vector<Vector<double>> & computed_quantities) const
3987  {
3988  const unsigned int n_quadrature_points = inputs.solution_values.size();
3989  Assert(inputs.solution_gradients.size() == n_quadrature_points,
3990  ExcInternalError());
3991  Assert(computed_quantities.size() == n_quadrature_points,
3992  ExcInternalError());
3993  Assert(inputs.solution_values[0].size() == dim + 2, ExcInternalError());
3994 *
3995  for (unsigned int q = 0; q < n_quadrature_points; ++q)
3996  {
3997  for (unsigned int d = 0; d < dim; ++d)
3998  computed_quantities[q](d) = (inputs.solution_values[q](d)
3999  EquationData::year_in_seconds 100);
4000 *
4001  const double pressure =
4002  (inputs.solution_values[q](dim)
4003 *
4004 - minimal_pressure);
4005  computed_quantities[q](dim) = pressure;
4006 *
4007  const double temperature = inputs.solution_values[q](dim + 1);
4008  computed_quantities[q](dim + 1) = temperature;
4009 *
4010  Tensor<2, dim> grad_u;
4011  for (unsigned int d = 0; d < dim; ++d)
4012  grad_u[d] = inputs.solution_gradients[q][d];
4013  const SymmetricTensor<2, dim> strain_rate = symmetrize(grad_u);
4014  computed_quantities[q](dim + 2) =
4015  2 EquationData::eta strain_rate strain_rate;
4016 *
4017  computed_quantities[q](dim + 3) = partition;
4018  }
4019  }
4020 *
4021 
4022  @endcode
4023 *
4024 * The <code>output_results()</code> function has a similar task to the one in @ref step_31 "step-31" . However, here we are going to demonstrate a different technique on how to merge output from different DoFHandler objects. The way we're going to achieve this recombination is to create a joint DoFHandler that collects both components, the Stokes solution and the temperature solution. This can be nicely done by combining the finite elements from the two systems to form one FESystem, and let this collective system define a new DoFHandler object. To be sure that everything was done correctly, we perform a sanity check that ensures that we got all the dofs from both Stokes and temperature even in the combined system. We then combine the data vectors. Unfortunately, there is no straight-forward relation that tells us how to sort Stokes and temperature vector into the joint vector. The way we can get around this trouble is to rely on the information collected in the FESystem. For each dof on a cell, the joint finite element knows to which equation component (velocity component, pressure, or temperature) it belongs – that's the information we need! So we step through all cells (with iterators into all three DoFHandlers moving in sync), and for each joint cell dof, we read out that component using the FiniteElement::system_to_base_index function (see there for a description of what the various parts of its return value contain). We also need to keep track whether we're on a Stokes dof or a temperature dof, which is contained in joint_fe.system_to_base_index(i).first.first. Eventually, the dof_indices data structures on either of the three systems tell us how the relation between global vector and local dofs looks like on the present cell, which concludes this tedious work. We make sure that each processor only works on the subdomain it owns locally (and not on ghost or artificial cells) when building the joint solution vector. The same will then have to be done in DataOut::build_patches(), but that function does so automatically.
4025 * What we end up with is a set of patches that we can write using the functions in DataOutBase in a variety of output formats. Here, we then have to pay attention that what each processor writes is really only its own part of the domain, i.e. we will want to write each processor's contribution into a separate file. This we do by adding an additional number to the filename when we write the solution. This is not really new, we did it similarly in @ref step_40 "step-40" . Note that we write in the compressed format @p .vtu instead of plain vtk files, which saves quite some storage.
4026 * All the rest of the work is done in the PostProcessor class.
4027 *
4028 
4029 *
4030 * @code
4031  template <int dim>
4032  void BoussinesqFlowProblem<dim>::output_results()
4033  {
4034  TimerOutput::Scope timer_section(computing_timer, "Postprocessing");
4035 *
4036  const FESystem<dim> joint_fe(stokes_fe, 1, temperature_fe, 1);
4037 *
4038  DoFHandler<dim> joint_dof_handler(triangulation);
4039  joint_dof_handler.distribute_dofs(joint_fe);
4040  Assert(joint_dof_handler.n_dofs() ==
4041  stokes_dof_handler.n_dofs() + temperature_dof_handler.n_dofs(),
4042  ExcInternalError());
4043 *
4044  TrilinosWrappers::MPI::Vector joint_solution;
4045  joint_solution.reinit(joint_dof_handler.locally_owned_dofs(),
4046  MPI_COMM_WORLD);
4047 *
4048  {
4049  std::vector<types::global_dof_index> local_joint_dof_indices(
4050  joint_fe.n_dofs_per_cell());
4051  std::vector<types::global_dof_index> local_stokes_dof_indices(
4052  stokes_fe.n_dofs_per_cell());
4053  std::vector<types::global_dof_index> local_temperature_dof_indices(
4054  temperature_fe.n_dofs_per_cell());
4055 *
4056  typename DoFHandler<dim>::active_cell_iterator
4057  joint_cell = joint_dof_handler.begin_active(),
4058  joint_endc = joint_dof_handler.end(),
4059  stokes_cell = stokes_dof_handler.begin_active(),
4060  temperature_cell = temperature_dof_handler.begin_active();
4061  for (; joint_cell != joint_endc;
4062  ++joint_cell, ++stokes_cell, ++temperature_cell)
4063  if (joint_cell->is_locally_owned())
4064  {
4065  joint_cell->get_dof_indices(local_joint_dof_indices);
4066  stokes_cell->get_dof_indices(local_stokes_dof_indices);
4067  temperature_cell->get_dof_indices(local_temperature_dof_indices);
4068 *
4069  for (unsigned int i = 0; i < joint_fe.n_dofs_per_cell(); ++i)
4070  if (joint_fe.system_to_base_index(i).first.first == 0)
4071  {
4072  Assert(joint_fe.system_to_base_index(i).second <
4073  local_stokes_dof_indices.size(),
4074  ExcInternalError());
4075 *
4076  joint_solution(local_joint_dof_indices[i]) = stokes_solution(
4077  local_stokes_dof_indices[joint_fe.system_to_base_index(i)
4078  .second]);
4079  }
4080  else
4081  {
4082  Assert(joint_fe.system_to_base_index(i).first.first == 1,
4083  ExcInternalError());
4084  Assert(joint_fe.system_to_base_index(i).second <
4085  local_temperature_dof_indices.size(),
4086  ExcInternalError());
4087  joint_solution(local_joint_dof_indices[i]) =
4088  temperature_solution(
4089  local_temperature_dof_indices
4090  [joint_fe.system_to_base_index(i).second]);
4091  }
4092  }
4093  }
4094 *
4095  joint_solution.compress(VectorOperation::insert);
4096 *
4097  IndexSet locally_relevant_joint_dofs(joint_dof_handler.n_dofs());
4098  DoFTools::extract_locally_relevant_dofs(joint_dof_handler,
4099  locally_relevant_joint_dofs);
4100  TrilinosWrappers::MPI::Vector locally_relevant_joint_solution;
4101  locally_relevant_joint_solution.reinit(locally_relevant_joint_dofs,
4102  MPI_COMM_WORLD);
4103  locally_relevant_joint_solution = joint_solution;
4104 *
4105  Postprocessor postprocessor(Utilities::MPI::this_mpi_process(
4106  MPI_COMM_WORLD),
4107  stokes_solution.block(1).min());
4108 *
4109  DataOut<dim> data_out;
4110  data_out.attach_dof_handler(joint_dof_handler);
4111  data_out.add_data_vector(locally_relevant_joint_solution, postprocessor);
4112  data_out.build_patches();
4113 *
4114  static int out_index = 0;
4115  data_out.write_vtu_with_pvtu_record(
4116  "./", "solution", out_index, MPI_COMM_WORLD, 5);
4117 *
4118  out_index++;
4119  }
4120 *
4121 
4122 *
4123  @endcode
4124 *
4125 * <a name="BoussinesqFlowProblemrefine_mesh"></a> <h4>BoussinesqFlowProblem::refine_mesh</h4>
4126 *
4127 
4128 *
4129 * This function isn't really new either. Since the <code>setup_dofs</code> function that we call in the middle has its own timer section, we split timing this function into two sections. It will also allow us to easily identify which of the two is more expensive.
4130 * One thing of note, however, is that we only want to compute error indicators on the locally owned subdomain. In order to achieve this, we pass one additional argument to the KellyErrorEstimator::estimate function. Note that the vector for error estimates is resized to the number of active cells present on the current process, which is less than the total number of active cells on all processors (but more than the number of locally owned active cells); each processor only has a few coarse cells around the locally owned ones, as also explained in @ref step_40 "step-40" .
4131 * The local error estimates are then handed to a %parallel version of GridRefinement (in namespace parallel::distributed::GridRefinement, see also @ref step_40 "step-40" ) which looks at the errors and finds the cells that need refinement by comparing the error values across processors. As in @ref step_31 "step-31" , we want to limit the maximum grid level. So in case some cells have been marked that are already at the finest level, we simply clear the refine flags.
4132 *
4133 
4134 *
4135 * @code
4136  template <int dim>
4137  void
4138  BoussinesqFlowProblem<dim>::refine_mesh(const unsigned int max_grid_level)
4139  {
4140  parallel::distributed::SolutionTransfer<dim, TrilinosWrappers::MPI::Vector>
4141  temperature_trans(temperature_dof_handler);
4142  parallel::distributed::SolutionTransfer<dim,
4143  TrilinosWrappers::MPI::BlockVector>
4144  stokes_trans(stokes_dof_handler);
4145 *
4146  {
4147  TimerOutput::Scope timer_section(computing_timer,
4148  "Refine mesh structure, part 1");
4149 *
4150  Vector<float> estimated_error_per_cell(triangulation.n_active_cells());
4151 *
4152  KellyErrorEstimator<dim>::estimate(
4153  temperature_dof_handler,
4154  QGauss<dim
4155 *
4156 - 1>(parameters.temperature_degree + 1),
4157  std::map<types::boundary_id, const Function<dim>>(),
4158  temperature_solution,
4159  estimated_error_per_cell,
4160  ComponentMask(),
4161  nullptr,
4162  0,
4163  triangulation.locally_owned_subdomain());
4164 *
4165  parallel::distributed::GridRefinement::refine_and_coarsen_fixed_fraction(
4166  triangulation, estimated_error_per_cell, 0.3, 0.1);
4167 *
4168  if (triangulation.n_levels() > max_grid_level)
4169  for (typename Triangulation<dim>::active_cell_iterator cell =
4170  triangulation.begin_active(max_grid_level);
4171  cell != triangulation.end();
4172  ++cell)
4173  cell->clear_refine_flag();
4174 *
4175  @endcode
4176 *
4177 * With all flags marked as necessary, we can then tell the parallel::distributed::SolutionTransfer objects to get ready to transfer data from one mesh to the next, which they will do when notified by Triangulation as part of the @p execute_coarsening_and_refinement() call. The syntax is similar to the non-%parallel solution transfer (with the exception that here a pointer to the vector entries is enough). The remainder of the function further down below is then concerned with setting up the data structures again after mesh refinement and restoring the solution vectors on the new mesh.
4178 *
4179 
4180 *
4181 * @code
4182  std::vector<const TrilinosWrappers::MPI::Vector> x_temperature(2);
4183  x_temperature[0] = &temperature_solution;
4184  x_temperature[1] = &old_temperature_solution;
4185  std::vector<const TrilinosWrappers::MPI::BlockVector> x_stokes(2);
4186  x_stokes[0] = &stokes_solution;
4187  x_stokes[1] = &old_stokes_solution;
4188 *
4189  triangulation.prepare_coarsening_and_refinement();
4190 *
4191  temperature_trans.prepare_for_coarsening_and_refinement(x_temperature);
4192  stokes_trans.prepare_for_coarsening_and_refinement(x_stokes);
4193 *
4194  triangulation.execute_coarsening_and_refinement();
4195  }
4196 *
4197  setup_dofs();
4198 *
4199  {
4200  TimerOutput::Scope timer_section(computing_timer,
4201  "Refine mesh structure, part 2");
4202 *
4203  {
4204  TrilinosWrappers::MPI::Vector distributed_temp1(temperature_rhs);
4205  TrilinosWrappers::MPI::Vector distributed_temp2(temperature_rhs);
4206 *
4207  std::vector<TrilinosWrappers::MPI::Vector> tmp(2);
4208  tmp[0] = &(distributed_temp1);
4209  tmp[1] = &(distributed_temp2);
4210  temperature_trans.interpolate(tmp);
4211 *
4212  @endcode
4213 *
4214 * enforce constraints to make the interpolated solution conforming on the new mesh:
4215 *
4216 
4217 *
4218 * @code
4219  temperature_constraints.distribute(distributed_temp1);
4220  temperature_constraints.distribute(distributed_temp2);
4221 *
4222  temperature_solution = distributed_temp1;
4223  old_temperature_solution = distributed_temp2;
4224  }
4225 *
4226  {
4227  TrilinosWrappers::MPI::BlockVector distributed_stokes(stokes_rhs);
4228  TrilinosWrappers::MPI::BlockVector old_distributed_stokes(stokes_rhs);
4229 *
4230  std::vector<TrilinosWrappers::MPI::BlockVector> stokes_tmp(2);
4231  stokes_tmp[0] = &(distributed_stokes);
4232  stokes_tmp[1] = &(old_distributed_stokes);
4233 *
4234  stokes_trans.interpolate(stokes_tmp);
4235 *
4236  @endcode
4237 *
4238 * enforce constraints to make the interpolated solution conforming on the new mesh:
4239 *
4240 
4241 *
4242 * @code
4243  stokes_constraints.distribute(distributed_stokes);
4244  stokes_constraints.distribute(old_distributed_stokes);
4245 *
4246  stokes_solution = distributed_stokes;
4247  old_stokes_solution = old_distributed_stokes;
4248  }
4249  }
4250  }
4251 *
4252 
4253 *
4254  @endcode
4255 *
4256 * <a name="BoussinesqFlowProblemrun"></a> <h4>BoussinesqFlowProblem::run</h4>
4257 *
4258 
4259 *
4260 * This is the final and controlling function in this class. It, in fact, runs the entire rest of the program and is, once more, very similar to @ref step_31 "step-31" . The only substantial difference is that we use a different mesh now (a GridGenerator::hyper_shell instead of a simple cube geometry).
4261 *
4262 
4263 *
4264 * @code
4265  template <int dim>
4266  void BoussinesqFlowProblem<dim>::run()
4267  {
4268  GridGenerator::hyper_shell(triangulation,
4269  Point<dim>(),
4270  EquationData::R0,
4271  EquationData::R1,
4272  (dim == 3) ? 96 : 12,
4273  true);
4274 *
4275  global_Omega_diameter = GridTools::diameter(triangulation);
4276 *
4277  triangulation.refine_global(parameters.initial_global_refinement);
4278 *
4279  setup_dofs();
4280 *
4281  unsigned int pre_refinement_step = 0;
4282 *
4283  start_time_iteration:
4284 *
4285  {
4286  TrilinosWrappers::MPI::Vector solution(
4287  temperature_dof_handler.locally_owned_dofs());
4288  @endcode
4289 *
4290 * VectorTools::project supports parallel vector classes with most standard finite elements via deal.II's own native MatrixFree framework: since we use standard Lagrange elements of moderate order this function works well here.
4291 *
4292 
4293 *
4294 * @code
4295  VectorTools::project(temperature_dof_handler,
4296  temperature_constraints,
4297  QGauss<dim>(parameters.temperature_degree + 2),
4298  EquationData::TemperatureInitialValues<dim>(),
4299  solution);
4300  @endcode
4301 *
4302 * Having so computed the current temperature field, let us set the member variable that holds the temperature nodes. Strictly speaking, we really only need to set <code>old_temperature_solution</code> since the first thing we will do is to compute the Stokes solution that only requires the previous time step's temperature field. That said, nothing good can come from not initializing the other vectors as well (especially since it's a relatively cheap operation and we only have to do it once at the beginning of the program) if we ever want to extend our numerical method or physical model, and so we initialize <code>old_temperature_solution</code> and <code>old_old_temperature_solution</code> as well. The assignment makes sure that the vectors on the left hand side (which where initialized to contain ghost elements as well) also get the correct ghost elements. In other words, the assignment here requires communication between processors:
4303 *
4304 
4305 *
4306 * @code
4307  temperature_solution = solution;
4308  old_temperature_solution = solution;
4309  old_old_temperature_solution = solution;
4310  }
4311 *
4312  timestep_number = 0;
4313  time_step = old_time_step = 0;
4314 *
4315  double time = 0;
4316 *
4317  do
4318  {
4319  pcout << "Timestep " << timestep_number
4320  << ": t=" << time / EquationData::year_in_seconds << " years"
4321  << std::endl;
4322 *
4323  assemble_stokes_system();
4324  build_stokes_preconditioner();
4325  assemble_temperature_matrix();
4326 *
4327  solve();
4328 *
4329  pcout << std::endl;
4330 *
4331  if ((timestep_number == 0) &&
4332  (pre_refinement_step < parameters.initial_adaptive_refinement))
4333  {
4334  refine_mesh(parameters.initial_global_refinement +
4335  parameters.initial_adaptive_refinement);
4336  ++pre_refinement_step;
4337  goto start_time_iteration;
4338  }
4339  else if ((timestep_number > 0) &&
4340  (timestep_number % parameters.adaptive_refinement_interval ==
4341  0))
4342  refine_mesh(parameters.initial_global_refinement +
4343  parameters.initial_adaptive_refinement);
4344 *
4345  if ((parameters.generate_graphical_output == true) &&
4346  (timestep_number % parameters.graphical_output_interval == 0))
4347  output_results();
4348 *
4349  @endcode
4350 *
4351 * In order to speed up linear solvers, we extrapolate the solutions from the old time levels to the new one. This gives a very good initial guess, cutting the number of iterations needed in solvers by more than one half. We do not need to extrapolate in the last iteration, so if we reached the final time, we stop here.
4352 * As the last thing during a time step (before actually bumping up the number of the time step), we check whether the current time step number is divisible by 100, and if so we let the computing timer print a summary of CPU times spent so far.
4353 *
4354 
4355 *
4356 * @code
4357  if (time > parameters.end_time EquationData::year_in_seconds)
4358  break;
4359 *
4360  TrilinosWrappers::MPI::BlockVector old_old_stokes_solution;
4361  old_old_stokes_solution = old_stokes_solution;
4362  old_stokes_solution = stokes_solution;
4363  old_old_temperature_solution = old_temperature_solution;
4364  old_temperature_solution = temperature_solution;
4365  if (old_time_step > 0)
4366  {
4367  @endcode
4368 *
4369 * Trilinos sadd does not like ghost vectors even as input. Copy into distributed vectors for now:
4370 *
4371 
4372 *
4373 * @code
4374  {
4375  TrilinosWrappers::MPI::BlockVector distr_solution(stokes_rhs);
4376  distr_solution = stokes_solution;
4377  TrilinosWrappers::MPI::BlockVector distr_old_solution(stokes_rhs);
4378  distr_old_solution = old_old_stokes_solution;
4379  distr_solution.sadd(1. + time_step / old_time_step,
4380 *
4381 
4382 
4383 *
4384 *
4385 
4386 
4387 *
4388 *
4389 
4390 
4391 *
4392 *
4393 
4394 
4395 *
4396 *
4397 
4398 
4399 *
4400 *
4401 
4402 
4403 *
4404 *
4405 
4406 
4407 *
4408 *
4409 
4410 
4411 *
4412 *
4413 
4414 
4415 *
4416 *
4417 
4418 
4419 *
4420 *
4421 
4422 
4423 *
4424 *
4425 
4426 
4427 *
4428 *
4429 
4430 
4431 *
4432 *
4433 
4434 
4435 *
4436 *
4437 
4438 
4439 *
4440 *
4441 
4442 
4443 *
4444 *
4445 
4446 
4447 *
4448 *
4449 
4450 
4451 *
4452 *
4453 
4454 
4455 *
4456 *
4457 
4458 
4459 *
4460 *
4461 
4462 
4463 *
4464 *
4465 
4466 
4467 *
4468 *
4469 
4470 
4471 *
4472 *
4473 
4474 
4475 *
4476 *
4477 
4478 
4479 *
4480 *
4481 
4482 
4483 *
4484 *
4485 
4486 
4487 *
4488 *
4489 
4490 
4491 *
4492 *
4493 
4494 
4495 *
4496 *
4497 
4498 
4499 *
4500 *
4501 
4502 
4503 *
4504 *
4505 
4506 
4507 *
4508 *
4509 
4510 
4511 *
4512 *
4513 
4514 
4515 *
4516 *
4517 
4518 
4519 *
4520 *
4521 -time_step / old_time_step,
4522  distr_old_solution);
4523  stokes_solution = distr_solution;
4524  }
4525  {
4526  TrilinosWrappers::MPI::Vector distr_solution(temperature_rhs);
4527  distr_solution = temperature_solution;
4528  TrilinosWrappers::MPI::Vector distr_old_solution(temperature_rhs);
4529  distr_old_solution = old_old_temperature_solution;
4530  distr_solution.sadd(1. + time_step / old_time_step,
4531 *
4532 
4533 
4534 *
4535 *
4536 
4537 
4538 *
4539 *
4540 
4541 
4542 *
4543 *
4544 
4545 
4546 *
4547 *
4548 
4549 
4550 *
4551 *
4552 
4553 
4554 *
4555 *
4556 
4557 
4558 *
4559 *
4560 
4561 
4562 *
4563 *
4564 
4565 
4566 *
4567 *
4568 
4569 
4570 *
4571 *
4572 
4573 
4574 *
4575 *
4576 
4577 
4578 *
4579 *
4580 
4581 
4582 *
4583 *
4584 
4585 
4586 *
4587 *
4588 
4589 
4590 *
4591 *
4592 
4593 
4594 *
4595 *
4596 
4597 
4598 *
4599 *
4600 
4601 
4602 *
4603 *
4604 
4605 
4606 *
4607 *
4608 
4609 
4610 *
4611 *
4612 
4613 
4614 *
4615 *
4616 
4617 
4618 *
4619 *
4620 
4621 
4622 *
4623 *
4624 
4625 
4626 *
4627 *
4628 
4629 
4630 *
4631 *
4632 
4633 
4634 *
4635 *
4636 
4637 
4638 *
4639 *
4640 
4641 
4642 *
4643 *
4644 
4645 
4646 *
4647 *
4648 
4649 
4650 *
4651 *
4652 
4653 
4654 *
4655 *
4656 
4657 
4658 *
4659 *
4660 
4661 
4662 *
4663 *
4664 
4665 
4666 *
4667 *
4668 
4669 
4670 *
4671 *
4672 -time_step / old_time_step,
4673  distr_old_solution);
4674  temperature_solution = distr_solution;
4675  }
4676  }
4677 *
4678  if ((timestep_number > 0) && (timestep_number % 100 == 0))
4679  computing_timer.print_summary();
4680 *
4681  time += time_step;
4682  ++timestep_number;
4683  }
4684  while (true);
4685 *
4686  @endcode
4687 *
4688 * If we are generating graphical output, do so also for the last time step unless we had just done so before we left the do-while loop
4689 *
4690 
4691 *
4692 * @code
4693  if ((parameters.generate_graphical_output == true) &&
4694  !((timestep_number
4695 *
4696 - 1) % parameters.graphical_output_interval == 0))
4697  output_results();
4698  }
4699  } // namespace Step32
4700 *
4701 
4702 *
4703  @endcode
4704 *
4705 * <a name="Thecodemaincodefunction"></a> <h3>The <code>main</code> function</h3>
4706 *
4707 
4708 *
4709 * The main function is short as usual and very similar to the one in @ref step_31 "step-31" . Since we use a parameter file which is specified as an argument in the command line, we have to read it in here and pass it on to the Parameters class for parsing. If no filename is given in the command line, we simply use the <code>step-32.prm</code> file which is distributed together with the program.
4710 *
4711 
4712 *
4713 * Because 3d computations are simply very slow unless you throw a lot of processors at them, the program defaults to 2d. You can get the 3d version by changing the constant dimension below to 3.
4714 *
4715 
4716 *
4717 * @code
4718  int main(int argc, charargv[])
4719  {
4720  try
4721  {
4722  using namespace Step32;
4723  using namespace dealii;
4724 *
4725  Utilities::MPI::MPI_InitFinalize mpi_initialization(
4726  argc, argv, numbers::invalid_unsigned_int);
4727 *
4728  std::string parameter_filename;
4729  if (argc >= 2)
4730  parameter_filename = argv[1];
4731  else
4732  parameter_filename = "step-32.prm";
4733 *
4734  const int dim = 2;
4735  BoussinesqFlowProblem<dim>::Parameters parameters(parameter_filename);
4736  BoussinesqFlowProblem<dim> flow_problem(parameters);
4737  flow_problem.run();
4738  }
4739  catch (std::exception &exc)
4740  {
4741  std::cerr << std::endl
4742  << std::endl
4743  << "----------------------------------------------------"
4744  << std::endl;
4745  std::cerr << "Exception on processing: " << std::endl
4746  << exc.what() << std::endl
4747  << "Aborting!" << std::endl
4748  << "----------------------------------------------------"
4749  << std::endl;
4750 *
4751  return 1;
4752  }
4753  catch (...)
4754  {
4755  std::cerr << std::endl
4756  << std::endl
4757  << "----------------------------------------------------"
4758  << std::endl;
4759  std::cerr << "Unknown exception!" << std::endl
4760  << "Aborting!" << std::endl
4761  << "----------------------------------------------------"
4762  << std::endl;
4763  return 1;
4764  }
4765 *
4766  return 0;
4767  }
4768  @endcode
4769 * <a name="Results"></a><h1>Results</h1>
4770 *
4771 
4772 * When run, the program simulates convection in 3d in much the same wayas @ref step_31 "step-31" did, though with an entirely different testcase.
4773 *
4774 
4775 * <a name="Comparisonofresultswithstep31"></a><h3>Comparison of results with step-31</h3>
4776 *
4777 
4778 * Before we go to this testcase, however, let us show a few results from aslightly earlier version of this program that was solving exactly thetestcase we used in @ref step_31 "step-31" , just that we now solve it in parallel and withmuch higher resolution. We show these results mainly for comparison.
4779 * Here are two images that show this higher resolution if we choose a 3dcomputation in <code>main()</code> and if we set <code>initial_refinement=3</code> and <code>n_pre_refinement_steps=4</code> . At the time steps shown, themeshes had around 72,000 and 236,000 cells, for a total of 2,680,000and 8,250,000 degrees of freedom, respectively, more than an order ofmagnitude more than we had available in @ref step_31 "step-31" :
4780 * <table align="center" class="doxtable">
4781  <tr>
4782  <td>
4783  <img src="https://www.dealii.org/images/steps/developer/step-32.3d.cube.0.png" alt="">
4784  </td>
4785  </tr>
4786  <tr>
4787  <td>
4788  <img src="https://www.dealii.org/images/steps/developer/step-32.3d.cube.1.png" alt="">
4789  </td>
4790  </tr>
4791 </table>
4792 * The computation was done on a subset of 50 processors of the Brazoscluster at Texas A&amp;M University.
4793 *
4794 
4795 * <a name="Resultsfora2dcircularshelltestcase"></a><h3>Results for a 2d circular shell testcase</h3>
4796 *
4797 
4798 * Next, we will run @ref step_32 "step-32" with the parameter file in the directory with onechange: we increase the final time to 1e9. Here we are using 16 processors. Thecommand to launch is (note that @ref step_32 "step-32" .prm is the default):
4799 * <code><pre>\ @f$ mpirun
4800 *
4801 -np 16 ./step-32
4802 </pre>
4803 </code>
4804 *
4805 Note that running a job on a cluster typically requires going through a job
4806 scheduler, which we won't discuss here. The output will look roughly like
4807 this:
4808 *
4809 <code>
4810 <pre>
4811 $ mpirun
4812 *
4813 * - p 16 ./ @ref step_32 "step-32" Number of active cells: 12,288 (on 6 levels)Number of degrees of freedom: 186,624 (99,840+36,864+49,920)
4814 * Timestep 0: t=0 years
4815 * Rebuilding Stokes preconditioner... Solving Stokes system... 41 iterations. Maximal velocity: 60.4935 cm/year Time step: 18166.9 years 17 CG iterations for temperature Temperature range: 973 4273.16
4816 * Number of active cells: 15,921 (on 7 levels)Number of degrees of freedom: 252,723 (136,640+47,763+68,320)
4817 * Timestep 0: t=0 years
4818 * Rebuilding Stokes preconditioner... Solving Stokes system... 50 iterations. Maximal velocity: 60.3223 cm/year Time step: 10557.6 years 19 CG iterations for temperature Temperature range: 973 4273.16
4819 * Number of active cells: 19,926 (on 8 levels)Number of degrees of freedom: 321,246 (174,312+59,778+87,156)
4820 * Timestep 0: t=0 years
4821 * Rebuilding Stokes preconditioner... Solving Stokes system... 50 iterations. Maximal velocity: 57.8396 cm/year Time step: 5453.78 years 18 CG iterations for temperature Temperature range: 973 4273.16
4822 * Timestep 1: t=5453.78 years
4823 * Solving Stokes system... 49 iterations. Maximal velocity: 59.0231 cm/year Time step: 5345.86 years 18 CG iterations for temperature Temperature range: 973 4273.16
4824 * Timestep 2: t=10799.6 years
4825 * Solving Stokes system... 24 iterations. Maximal velocity: 60.2139 cm/year Time step: 5241.51 years 17 CG iterations for temperature Temperature range: 973 4273.16
4826 * [...]
4827 * Timestep 100: t=272151 years
4828 * Solving Stokes system... 21 iterations. Maximal velocity: 161.546 cm/year Time step: 1672.96 years 17 CG iterations for temperature Temperature range: 973 4282.57
4829 * Number of active cells: 56,085 (on 8 levels)Number of degrees of freedom: 903,408 (490,102+168,255+245,051)
4830 *
4831 
4832 *
4833 * +---------------------------------------------+------------+------------+| Total wallclock time elapsed since start | 115s | || | | || Section | no. calls | wall time | % of total |+---------------------------------+-----------+------------+------------+| Assemble Stokes system | 103 | 2.82s | 2.5% || Assemble temperature matrices | 12 | 0.452s | 0.39% || Assemble temperature rhs | 103 | 11.5s | 10% || Build Stokes preconditioner | 12 | 2.09s | 1.8% || Solve Stokes system | 103 | 90.4s | 79% || Solve temperature system | 103 | 1.53s | 1.3% || Postprocessing | 3 | 0.532s | 0.46% || Refine mesh structure, part 1 | 12 | 0.93s | 0.81% || Refine mesh structure, part 2 | 12 | 0.384s | 0.33% || Setup dof systems | 13 | 2.96s | 2.6% |+---------------------------------+-----------+------------+------------+
4834 * [...]
4835 * +---------------------------------------------+------------+------------+| Total wallclock time elapsed since start | 9.14e+04s | || | | || Section | no. calls | wall time | % of total |+---------------------------------+-----------+------------+------------+| Assemble Stokes system | 47045 | 2.05e+03s | 2.2% || Assemble temperature matrices | 4707 | 310s | 0.34% || Assemble temperature rhs | 47045 | 8.7e+03s | 9.5% || Build Stokes preconditioner | 4707 | 1.48e+03s | 1.6% || Solve Stokes system | 47045 | 7.34e+04s | 80% || Solve temperature system | 47045 | 1.46e+03s | 1.6% || Postprocessing | 1883 | 222s | 0.24% || Refine mesh structure, part 1 | 4706 | 641s | 0.7% || Refine mesh structure, part 2 | 4706 | 259s | 0.28% || Setup dof systems | 4707 | 1.86e+03s | 2% |+---------------------------------+-----------+------------+------------+</pre></code>
4836 * The simulation terminates when the time reaches the 1 billion yearsselected in the input file. You can extrapolate from this how long asimulation would take for a different final time (the time step sizeultimately settles on somewhere around 20,000 years, so computing fortwo billion years will take 100,000 time steps, give or take 20%). Ascan be seen here, we spend most of the compute time in assemblinglinear systems and &mdash; above all &mdash; in solving Stokessystems.
4837 *
4838 
4839 * To demonstrate the output we show the output from every 1250th time step here: <table>
4840  <tr>
4841  <td>
4842  <img src="https://www.dealii.org/images/steps/developer/step-32-2d-time-000.png" alt="">
4843  </td>
4844  <td>
4845  <img src="https://www.dealii.org/images/steps/developer/step-32-2d-time-050.png" alt="">
4846  </td>
4847  <td>
4848  <img src="https://www.dealii.org/images/steps/developer/step-32-2d-time-100.png" alt="">
4849  </td>
4850  </tr>
4851  <tr>
4852  <td>
4853  <img src="https://www.dealii.org/images/steps/developer/step-32-2d-time-150.png" alt="">
4854  </td>
4855  <td>
4856  <img src="https://www.dealii.org/images/steps/developer/step-32-2d-time-200.png" alt="">
4857  </td>
4858  <td>
4859  <img src="https://www.dealii.org/images/steps/developer/step-32-2d-time-250.png" alt="">
4860  </td>
4861  </tr>
4862  <tr>
4863  <td>
4864  <img src="https://www.dealii.org/images/steps/developer/step-32-2d-time-300.png" alt="">
4865  </td>
4866  <td>
4867  <img src="https://www.dealii.org/images/steps/developer/step-32-2d-time-350.png" alt="">
4868  </td>
4869  <td>
4870  <img src="https://www.dealii.org/images/steps/developer/step-32-2d-time-400.png" alt="">
4871  </td>
4872  </tr>
4873  <tr>
4874  <td>
4875  <img src="https://www.dealii.org/images/steps/developer/step-32-2d-time-450.png" alt="">
4876  </td>
4877  <td>
4878  <img src="https://www.dealii.org/images/steps/developer/step-32-2d-time-500.png" alt="">
4879  </td>
4880  <td>
4881  <img src="https://www.dealii.org/images/steps/developer/step-32-2d-time-550.png" alt="">
4882  </td>
4883  </tr>
4884  <tr>
4885  <td>
4886  <img src="https://www.dealii.org/images/steps/developer/step-32-2d-time-600.png" alt="">
4887  </td>
4888  <td>
4889  <img src="https://www.dealii.org/images/steps/developer/step-32-2d-cells.png" alt="">
4890  </td>
4891  <td>
4892  <img src="https://www.dealii.org/images/steps/developer/step-32-2d-partition.png" alt="">
4893  </td>
4894  </tr>
4895 </table>
4896 * The last two images show the grid as well as the partitioning of the mesh forthe same computation with 16 subdomains and 16 processors. The full dynamics ofthis simulation are really only visible by looking at an animation, for examplethe one <a
4897 href="https://www.dealii.org/images/steps/developer/step-32-2d-temperature.webm">shown
4898 on this site</a>. This image is well worth watching due to its artistic qualityand entrancing depiction of the evolution of the magma plumes.
4899 * If you watch the movie, you'll see that the convection pattern goesthrough several stages: First, it gets rid of the instable temperaturelayering with the hot material overlain by the dense coldmaterial. After this great driver is removed and we have a sort ofstable situation, a few blobs start to separate from the hot boundarylayer at the inner ring and rise up, with a few cold fingers alsodropping down from the outer boundary layer. During this phase, the solutionremains mostly symmetric, reflecting the 12-fold symmetry of theoriginal mesh.
